PREFACE
   This code of the City of Glenpool, as supplemented, contains ordinances up
to and including ordinance 826, passed April 7, 2025. Ordinances of the City
adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to the
extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the City
office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the code has
been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they have not been incorporated into
the code and they may not show the original ordinances in their entirety.
Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions concerning
the ordinances listed.
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 671
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING A COMPILATION AND CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR THE CITY OF
GLENPOOL, OKLAHOMA, TO BE KNOWN AS THE 2013 GLENPOOL CITY CODE, INCLUDING
ORDINANCES DEFINING PUBLIC OFFENSES AND PRESCRIBING PENALTIES FOR THE VIOLATION
THEREOF; REPEALING PREVIOUS CODIFICATIONS AND ORDINANCES IN CONFLICT THEREWITH
EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY EXCEPTED FROM REPEAL; PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE OF THE
2013 GLENPOOL CITY CODE; SAVING ALL PENDING PROCEEDINGS AND EXISTING RIGHTS AND
REMEDIES; PROVIDING FOR SEVERABILITY; AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
BE IT ORDAINED by the city council of the city of Glenpool, Oklahoma, as
follows:
Section 1.   Adoption Of The 2013 Glenpool City Code.
   From and after the date of passage of this ordinance as provided and to the
extent qualified by section 10 hereof, the city code of the city of Glenpool,
Oklahoma, as compiled and codified under the authority of the city council (the
city of Glenpool's governing body) and prepared pursuant to a certain
codification services contract with Sterling Codifiers, Inc., dated as of
December 12, 2009, containing the compilation of all ordinances of a general,
permanent and continuing nature, together with such subsequent changes and
amendments as may be made to said ordinances under the direction of the city
council, is hereby approved, adopted and ordained to be the code of ordinances
pertinent to all subjects and for all purposes set forth there in and shall be
accepted in all courts and for all purposes without question as the official
code and law of the city as duly enacted by the city council (the "2013
Glenpool city code"). The 2013 Glenpool city code, as hereby adopted, consists
of titles 1 - 12, inclusive, and all ordinances of a general and permanent
nature duly adopted up to and including ordinance no. 666, enacted December 3,
2012, and shall supersede all general and permanent ordinances of the city as
have been or shall be adopted on or before September 1, 2013, except as
otherwise provided herein. To the extent of any conflict between provisions of
any ordinance adopted after ordinance no. 666, enacted December 3, 2012, and
provisions of this 2013 Glenpool city code, the provisions of such ordinance(s)
as may have been adopted during the interim between December 3, 2012, and
September 1, 2013, shall control and shall be deemed to amend the 2013 Glenpool
city code with respect to any such conflicting provisions.
Section 2.   Supplemental And Amending Ordinances.
   Pursuant to title 11 Oklahoma Statutes § 14-108(A), there is hereby adopted,
as a method of perpetual codification, the loose-leaf type of binding together
with the continuous supplementing service provided by Sterling Codifiers, Inc.,
whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a general and permanent nature
supplementing, amending, altering, adding or deleting any provisions of the
2013 Glenpool city code, when such supplements, amendments, alterations,
additions or deletions have been enacted after September 1, 2013, in such form
as to indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part of the
2013 Glenpool city code, shall be deemed to be incorporated into the 2013
Glenpool city code, shall be identified by Sterling Codifiers with the proper
references and shall be inserted in the proper place in all designated official
copies; provided further that all ordinances, expressly including those of a
penal nature, shall be published and shall otherwise conform to the public
notification and filing requirements set forth herein for the codification of
the 2013 Glenpool city code as biennial supplements, thereby satisfying both
the decennial recodification and biennial supplementation requirements title 11
Oklahoma Statutes § 14-109.
Section 3.   Exceptions.
   No ordinances enacted by the city council after ordinance no. 666, which was
enacted on December 3, 2012, are included in the 2013 Glenpool city code as of
the effective date of this ordinance no. 671. Notwithstanding such omission,
all such ordinances shall continue in full force and effect from and after the
date of adoption and until repealed or amended.
Section 4.   Ordinances Of General Nature In Continuance Of Previously Adopted
Ordinances; Ordinances Of Special Nature Survive Adoption Of 2013 Glenpool City
Code.
   All ordinances of a general, permanent and continuing nature affecting the
public at-large of the city of Glenpool that are included in the 2013 Glenpool
city code shall be considered as continuations of any corresponding previously
adopted ordinance provisions and the fact that some provisions have been
deliberately eliminated by the city council from the 2013 Glenpool city code as
hereby adopted shall not cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness
of those ordinances that are included in the 2013 Glenpool city code. All
ordinances of a special nature, to include without limitation but by way of
example tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances, rights-of-way, budget ordinances,
rezoning ordinances, franchises, vacating ordinances and annexation ordinances,
are expressly excluded from the 2013 Glenpool city code but, regardless and
independent of such exclusion, shall continue in full force and effect unless
specifically repealed or amended by a provision of the 2013 Glenpool city code
or by subsequent special ordinance. Such ordinances shall not be included in
the official 2013 Glenpool city code.
Section 5.   Repeal.
   All ordinances of a general, permanent and continuing nature adopted on
final passage by the city council on or before September 1, 2013, but not
included in the 2013 Glenpool city code or expressly recognized and continued
in force by reference in section 1 of this ordinance, are hereby repealed and
shall be of no force or effect unless duly adopted upon reconsideration of all
or any part by the city council.
Section 6.   Unlawful Alteration.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to change or amend
by additions or deletions, any part or portion of the 2013 Glenpool city code,
or to insert or delete any pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper in
any way with any ordinance therein in such a manner as would cause the law of
the city to be altered or misrepresented thereby.
Section 7.   Directions To City Clerk And City Attorney.
   The city clerk and the city attorney are directed, upon passage of this
ordinance, to take all such other actions as may be necessary to comply with
the provisions of title 11 Oklahoma Statutes, article XIV, concerning the
codification and publication of city ordinances, to include without limitation
publication of the title and a summary of this ordinance and the 2013 Glenpool
city code adopted hereby and notification of the public by resolution of such
publication. One "master volume" and, as required by title 11 Oklahoma Statutes
§ 14-108(B), a minimum of three designated official copies shall at all times
be maintained in the office of the city clerk, certified as to correctness and
available for public use, inspection and examination at any and all times that
said office is regularly open. In the event of inadvertent failure to update
any other designated official copy of the 2013 Glenpool city code, the master
volume maintained in the office of the city clerk shall be deemed as
authoritative. As also required by title 11 Oklahoma Statutes § 14-108(B), the
city clerk shall keep on hand, or make upon request, copies of the 2013
Glenpool city code for distribution or sale at a reasonable price, as
determined by the city manager or her/his designee. As required by title 11
Oklahoma Statutes §§ 14-107(A), 14-108(C) and 14-110, the city clerk and city
attorney shall ensure the adoption of resolution no. 13-08-01 in the form
attached hereto and incorporated herein as "exhibit A" notifying the public of
publication of the 2013 Glenpool city code. As required by title 11 Oklahoma
Statutes § 14-110, the city clerk and city attorney shall further ensure that a
copy of such resolution shall be filed in the office of the Tulsa County court
clerk, and require a receipt in the form attached to resolution no. 13-08-01 to
include notation of book and page at which such resolution is recorded, and
that a complete volume of the 2013 Glenpool city code shall be deposited in the
Tulsa County law library. A copy of the 2013 Glenpool city code shall also be
uploaded and maintained in an on-line version, provided that any inadvertent
failure to maintain and post any amendments, supplements, additions or
deletions thereto shall not alter the full force and effect of the same. As
required by title 11 Oklahoma Statutes §§ 14-109 and 14-110, the city clerk and
city attorney shall further ensure that biennial supplements of ordinances
adopted subsequent to ordinance no. 666, enacted on December 3, 2012, are
published, that notification of publication is provided by resolution, that a
copy of each such supplement is delivered to the Tulsa County law library and
that a copy of each such resolution is filed with the Tulsa County clerk, all
as required for codification of the 2013 Glenpool city code.
Section 8.   Summary Of Contents And Notice Of Publication.
   As provided by title 11 Oklahoma Statutes §§ 14-106, 14-107(A) and 14-108
(C), the contents of this ordinance no. 671 and of the 2013 Glenpool city code
are summarized in "exhibit B" to this ordinance no. 671, are incorporated
herein by reference and shall be published within fifteen days of adoption of
this ordinance no. 671. Notice of the publication of the 2013 Glenpool city
code shall be in the manner provided for publication by title and summary of
compilations of codes and ordinances in title 11 Oklahoma Statutes § 14-107(A),
and as provided by resolution no. 13-08-01 referenced in section 7 of this
ordinance no. 671 in the form attached hereto and incorporated herein as
"exhibit A."
Section 9.   Savings Clause.
   Neither the repeal of any prior ordinances nor any provisions contained in
this ordinance shall be deemed or construed so as to impair, modify, alter,
limit or otherwise affect any rights, actions, claims or suits, whether now
pending in any court or not, that are now existing or which may arise or come
into existence before the effective date of the 2013 Glenpool city code.
Section 10.   Severability.
   If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this ordinance or any part
hereof is for any reason found to be invalid by a court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall be of no effect on the validity of the
remainder of this ordinance nor any part hereof.
Section 11.   Effective Date.
   This 2013 Glenpool city code shall be deemed to be in effect and in full
force and operation immediately as of 12:00:01 a.m. on Sunday, September 1,
2013, provided that ordinances enacted subsequently to ordinance no. 666,
adopted December 3, 2012, shall be deemed effective on the dates provided in
such ordinances.
PASSED AND APPROVED this 5th day of August 2013.
   /s/            
Momodou Ceesay, Mayor

EMERGENCY CLAUSE
WHEREAS, an emergency is declared to exist for the preservation of the public
peace, health, and safety of the city of Glenpool and the inhabitants thereof,
and more particularly to provide for the orderly continuation of the lawful and
necessary functions, operations and government of the city of Glenpool, by
reason whereof ordinance no. 671 shall take effect and be in full force
immediately from and after its passage and approval, as provided by law.
PASSED and this emergency clause ruled upon separately and approved, by
unanimous vote of all members of the city council, this 5th day of August 2013.

TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
GLENPOOL CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance Of Code
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Ordinances In Effect In Outlying Territory Of City
1-1-5: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the city council, this code is hereby declared to be and
shall hereafter constitute the official city code of Glenpool. This code of
ordinances shall be known and cited as the GLENPOOL CITY CODE and is hereby
published by authority of the city council and shall be supplemented to
incorporate the most recent legislation of the city as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. (2013 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE OF CODE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2013 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this code.
(2013 Code)
1-1-4: ORDINANCES IN EFFECT IN OUTLYING TERRITORY OF CITY:
   A.   Provisions Extended: All ordinances of the city now in effect within
the city are hereby extended to all real property belonging to or under the
control of the city outside the corporate limits of the city, and shall be in
full effect therein insofar as they are applicable. All ordinances of the city
which shall go into effect in the future shall also apply to and be in full
effect within the boundaries of all outlying real property insofar as they may
be applicable.
   B.   Word Interpretation: Any words in any ordinance indicating that the
effect of an ordinance provision is limited to the corporate limits of the city
shall be deemed to mean and include also the outlying real property belonging
to or under the control of the city, unless the context clearly indicates
otherwise. (2002 Code § 1.04.060)
1-1-5: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It is unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any
part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof,
or to alter or tamper with this code in any manner whatsoever which will cause
the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this
section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of an offense punishable as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this title and as set forth in the municipal bond schedule adopted by
the governing body as provided in section
1-11-19 of this title. (2013 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Certain Ordinances Not Affected By Code
1-2-2: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Effect Of Repeal; Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT AFFECTED BY CODE:
Nothing in this code or the ordinance adopting this code shall be construed to
repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following, and all such
ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the
same extent as if set out at length herein:
   A.   Any ordinance promising, obligating or guaranteeing the payment of
money for or to the city, authorizing the issuance of any municipal bonds or
any evidence of the city's indebtedness.
   B.   Any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of
taxes or for an annual budget.
   C.   Any ordinance creating specific sewer and paving districts and other
local improvement districts or otherwise relating to specific local
improvements and special assessments therefor.
   D.   Any ordinances calling or otherwise relating to specific elections.
   E.   Any ordinance annexing territory to the city or excluding territory as
a part of the city.
   F.   Any ordinance granting any franchise, permit or other right.
   G.   Any ordinance accepting the beneficial interest in any trust created by
a trust indenture.
   H.   Any ordinance approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to any
contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument.
   I.   Any temporary or special ordinance. (2002 Code § 1.04.080)
1-2-2: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this code, except as this code may
contain provisions for such matters, in which case, this code shall be
considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect to such
provisions only. (2013 Code)
1-2-3: EFFECT OF REPEAL; COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Reviving Prior Ordinance: The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive
any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took
effect.
   B.   Offenses: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as
to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done,
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or
claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any
such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   C.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   D.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the city herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this code. (2013 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this code,
or any codes or portions of codes adopted herein by reference, is for any
reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness of the remaining portions of this code, or any codes or portions
of codes adopted herein by reference. The city council hereby declares that it
would have passed each section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or
phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared
unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (2013 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATION
SECTION:
1-3-1: General Rules Of Interpretation
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the mayor and city council may be fully carried
out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare.
   C.   Computation Of Time: Whenever a notice is required to be given or an
act to be done in a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be held,
the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall not be counted
in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be held shall
be counted.
   D.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or some other city officer to do some act or perform some
duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other
officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   E.   Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or
more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such persons or officers.
   F.   May; Shall: The word "may" is permissive; the word "shall" is
mandatory.
   G.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   H.   Officers And Employees Generally: Whenever any officer or employee is
referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by
the words "of the city of Glenpool".
   I.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present. (2013 Code)
   J.   Gender: Words used in the masculine gender in this code or in other
ordinances of the city include the feminine and neuter unless a contrary
intention plainly appears. (2002 Code § 1.04.010)
   K.   Number: Words used in the singular number in this code or in other
ordinances of the city include the plural, and the plural the singular, except
where a contrary intention plainly appears. (2002 Code § 1.04.020)
   L.   Statutory References: Reference to the statutes of the state of
Oklahoma means the statutes as they now are or as they may be amended to be.
(2002 Code § 1.04.050; amd. 2013 Code)
   M.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the city
has been changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter", "section"
and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to city ordinances is not meant to
amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2013 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
CITY: The city of Glenpool, county of Tulsa, state of Oklahoma.
CITY COUNCIL: Unless otherwise indicated, the city council of the city of
Glenpool.
CODE: The city code of the city of Glenpool.
COUNTY: The county of Tulsa, state of Oklahoma.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
NUISANCE: The unlawful doing of an act, or omitting to perform a duty, which
act or omission disrupts the welfare of the city. The term is further defined
in section
6-5-2 of this code.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with
others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Includes natural persons, corporations (private and public),
partnerships and all other unincorporated organizations, trusts, estates,
governmental agencies, and other legal entities, except when a contrary
intention plainly appears.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
STATE: The state of Oklahoma.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law on any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person or, in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark. (2002 Code § 1.04.030; amd. 2013 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the sections and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
section hereof nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (2013
Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Municipal Court Costs And Fees
1-4-3: Application Of Provisions
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-5: Civil Relief For Violations
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
   A.   The maximum penalty, including fines, deferral fees in lieu of fines,
incarceration, community service, loss of license or privilege, orders of
abatement and costs of any court or administrative action, for the
nonperformance of acts required or the committing of acts prohibited by any
provision of this code may be as much as, but shall not exceed, the maximum
penalty established by state statute for the same offense. Without limitation,
administrative penalties for offenses with respect to the violation of specific
provisions of the zoning regulations, subdivision regulations, building
regulations, public nuisance regulations, animal regulations, health and safety
regulations, traffic regulations, offenses under title 6 of this code, or other
regulations and ordinances shall be as stated therein, respectively, or as
prescribed by statute; provided, that such administrative penalties may be
enforced judicially by the municipal court. (Ord. 642, 1-3-2011; amd. 2013
Code)
   B.   All violations of this code, including the enforcement of
administrative penalties as referenced in subsection A of this section, are
declared to be misdemeanors and are classified as either a class A offense or a
class B offense. A person convicted of a class A offense shall be punishable by
a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), excluding costs and fees,
and no incarceration. A person convicted of a class B offense shall be
punishable by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), plus costs
and fees, or incarceration in the city jail not exceeding ten (10) days, or
incarceration in the Tulsa County Jail not exceeding six (6) months, or by both
such fine and incarceration. (Ord. 660, 7-16-2012; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   The maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine for vehicular
offenses relating to speeding shall not exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00);
provided, that speeding in excess of thirty five (35) miles per hour may, in
the discretion of the arresting officer, be deemed reckless and subject to a
fine or deferral fee up to, but not exceeding, five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for the first offense, and up to, but not exceeding, one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for a second or subsequent offense. No fine or deferral fee in
connection with a parking violation shall exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00).
The maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine for alcohol related or drug
related vehicular offenses shall not exceed the lesser of eight hundred dollars
($800.00) or the statutory maximum, not including all applicable costs and
fees. For all other offenses, the maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a
fine that may be imposed shall be as set forth in subsection B of this section,
to the fullest extent allowed by statute.
   D.   A maximum fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), plus costs as
prescribed in this code, or incarceration not to exceed ninety (90) days, or
both such fine and incarceration, may be imposed for the violation of municipal
ordinances regulating the pretreatment of wastewater and regulating stormwater
discharges, as fixed by statute.
   E.   If any fine in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or
incarceration, or both such fine and incarceration, is available for any
offense, the person charged shall have the right to a jury trial, which right
may be waived only by such person charged. If trial by jury is waived, trial
shall be to the court and an election waiving jury trial may be reversed by the
defendant at any time prior to the date set for trial by the court. (Ord. 642,
1-3-2011; amd. 2013 Code)
1-4-2: MUNICIPAL COURT COSTS AND FEES 1 :

1-4-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: Unless expressly provided otherwise, the
penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of this
code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit or other
administrative penalty shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to
bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2013 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the city council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is
specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. (2013
Code)
1-4-5: CIVIL RELIEF FOR VIOLATIONS:
No penalty imposed by and pursuant to this code or other ordinance of the city
shall interfere with the right of the city to also apply to the proper courts
of the state for a mandamus, injunction or other appropriate action against a
person who violates or is about to violate any provision of this code or other
ordinance of the city. (2002 Code § 1.04.090)
CHAPTER 5
FORM OF GOVERNMENT
SECTION:
1-5-1: Council-Manager Form Of Government
1-5-2: City Departments
1-5-1: COUNCIL-MANAGER FORM OF GOVERNMENT:
The city is under the statutory council-manager form of government and shall
have all the powers, functions, rights, privileges, franchises and immunities
granted, or which may be granted, by state statute to cities under the
statutory council-manager form of government. Such powers, functions, rights,
privileges, franchises and immunities shall be exercised by the city as
provided by law, or if the manner is not therein prescribed, then in such
manner as the city council may prescribe. (2002 Code § 2.04.010; amd. 2013
Code)
1-5-2: CITY DEPARTMENTS:
There shall be the following departments in the city: police department, fire
department, department of law headed by the city attorney, city clerk
department, finance department, community development department, community
relations department, human resources department, public works department and
such other administrative departments, offices and agencies as the city council
may establish. (2002 Code § 2.04.020; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 6
CITY WARDS AND ELECTIONS
SECTION:
1-6-1: Number Of Wards; Changes
1-6-2: Election And Terms Of Council Members
1-6-3: Ward Boundaries Established
1-6-4: Modification Of Ward Boundaries
1-6-1: NUMBER OF WARDS; CHANGES:
The city is divided into four (4) wards. When a change in the number of wards
is made, the change shall go into effect for the next general election. If the
number of wards is increased from four (4) to six (6), the council member from
ward 5 shall be elected for a term to coincide with the terms of the council
members from wards 1 and 2, and the council member from ward 6 shall be elected
for a term to coincide with the terms of the council members from wards 3 and
4. (2002 Code § 1.08.010; amd. 2013 Code)
1-6-2: ELECTION AND TERMS OF COUNCIL MEMBERS:
   A.   At the first election held by the city, the council member from ward 1
and the council member from ward 2 shall be elected for terms of four (4)
years; the council member from ward 3, the council member from ward 4 and
council member at large shall be elected for terms of two (2) years. Every two
(2) years thereafter, the successors of those whose terms are expiring shall be
elected for overlapping terms of four (4) years, and shall serve until their
respective successors have been elected and qualify. (2002 Code § 1.08.010;
amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   A change in the number of wards or in the boundaries of wards shall not
affect the term for which a council member has been elected; and a council
member from a ward of a certain number before the change shall continue to be
the council member from the ward of that number after the change until his or
her term expires, although, in fact, he or she may no longer reside in the ward
of that number as newly constituted. (2002 Code § 1.08.010)
1-6-3: WARD BOUNDARIES ESTABLISHED:
The four (4) wards constituting the city of Glenpool shall consist of those
boundaries delineated and numbered one (1) through four (4) on the “Glenpool
Council District Boundaries Plan 1", as adopted by the city council meeting in
regular session on September 19, 2022, following public hearing on plans 1 and
2 on September 19, 2022, and as the same may be from time to time amended by
action of the city council. (2013 Code) (2013 Code; amd. Ord. 810, 9-19-2022)
1-6-4: MODIFICATION OF WARD BOUNDARIES:
Pursuant to 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 20-101, the ward boundaries shall be
modified if necessary to reflect population variations between such boundaries
as soon as practical after the results of each federal decennial census are
known. (2002 Code § 1.08.020)
CHAPTER 7
MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-7-1: Number Of Council Members; Qualifications; Term
1-7-2: Mayor And Vice Mayor
1-7-3: Compensation
1-7-4: Council Powers
1-7-5: Limitation Of Council Authority To Act Through City Manager
1-7-6: Meetings
1-7-7: Vacancies In Office
1-7-8: Authority To Secure Services
1-7-1: NUMBER OF COUNCIL MEMBERS; QUALIFICATIONS; TERM:
The city council shall be composed of one council member from each ward of the
city and one council member at large. The council members from the wards shall
be qualified electors of their respective wards at the time of their election;
but removal of a council member from one ward or precinct to another within the
city after his or her election, or a change in ward boundaries, shall not
disqualify him or her from completing the term for which he or she was elected.
The council member at large shall be a qualified elector of the city. If a
council member ceases to be a resident of the city, he or she shall thereupon
cease to be a council member. No council member may hold any position in the
city government by appointment by the city manager. Council terms begin
immediately upon the taking of public oath required by Oklahoma statute and
shall continue until respective successors are sworn in. (2002 Code § 2.08.010;
amd. 2013 Code)
1-7-2: MAYOR AND VICE MAYOR:
   A.   Election: The council shall elect from among its members a mayor and a
vice mayor. The mayor and vice mayor shall be elected in each odd numbered year
at the first council meeting held after council terms begin, or as soon
thereafter as practicable, and they shall serve until their respective
successors have been elected and qualified.
   B.   Duties:
      1.   Mayor: The mayor shall preside at meetings of the council, and shall
certify to the correct enrollment of all ordinances and resolutions passed
thereby. He or she shall be recognized as head of the city government for all
ceremonial purposes and by the governor for purposes of military law. He or she
shall have no regular administrative duties; except, that he or she shall sign
all conveyances and such other written obligations of the city as the council
may require. (2002 Code § 2.08.020)
      2.   Vice Mayor: The vice mayor shall act as mayor during the absence,
disability or suspension of the mayor, and if a vacancy occurs, shall become
mayor for the completion of the unexpired term.
   C.   Vacancy In Office Of Vice Mayor: If, by succession to the office of
mayor or otherwise, the office of vice mayor becomes vacant, the council shall
elect another vice mayor from among its members for completion of the unexpired
term. (2002 Code § 2.08.020; amd. 2013 Code)
1-7-3: COMPENSATION:
Neither the mayor, vice mayor nor any other council member of the city may
receive any compensation as such or for any other services rendered the city.
The mayor, vice mayor and any other council member may submit verified expenses
to the city treasurer for reimbursement. (2002 Code § 2.08.030; amd. Ord. 490,
11-18-2002; Ord. 529, 2-7-2005; 2013 Code)
1-7-4: COUNCIL POWERS:
Except as otherwise provided in this title, all powers of the city, including
the determination of all matters of policy, shall be vested in the city
council. Without limitation of the foregoing, the city council may: (2002 Code
§ 2.08.040; amd. 2013 Code)
   A.   Appoint and remove the city manager as provided by this title.
   B.   Enact municipal legislation subject to such limitations as may now or
hereafter be imposed by the Oklahoma constitution and law.
   C.   Raise revenue, make appropriations, regulate salaries and wages and all
other fiscal affairs of the city, subject to such limitations as may now or
hereafter be imposed by the Oklahoma constitution and law.
   D.   Inquire into the conduct of any office, department or agency of the
city, and investigate municipal affairs, or authorize and provide for such
inquiries. (2002 Code § 2.08.040)
   E.   Appoint or elect and remove members of commissions, boards, trust
authorities and other quasi-legislative or quasi-judicial officers as provided
by law, or prescribe the method of appointing or electing and removing them.
   F.   Create, change and abolish offices, departments and agencies
established by this code, and assign additional functions and duties to
offices, departments and agencies established by this code. (2002 Code §
2.08.040; amd. 2013 Code)
   G.   Grant pardons for violations of city ordinances, including the
remission of fines and costs, upon the recommendation of the municipal judge.
(2002 Code § 2.08.040)
1-7-5: LIMITATION OF COUNCIL AUTHORITY TO ACT THROUGH CITY MANAGER:
Except for the purposes of inquiry, the city council and its members shall deal
with the administrative service of the city solely through the city manager.
The council and its members may not:
   A.   Direct or request the city manager or other authority to appoint or
remove officers or employees;
   B.   Participate in any manner in the appointment or removal of officers and
employees of the city, except as provided by law; or
   C.   Give orders on ordinary administrative matters to any subordinate of
the city manager either publicly or privately. (2002 Code § 2.08.050)
1-7-6: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The city council shall meet regularly at least
bimonthly and shall hold its regularly scheduled meetings on the first and
third Mondays of each month at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and shall continue to
do so until changed by resolution or motion. If a meeting day falls on a
holiday, as designated by the city council, the regular meeting shall be held
on the next business day.
   B.   Special Meetings: The mayor or any three (3) council members may call
special meetings in accordance with procedures established by the Oklahoma open
meeting act. (2002 Code § 2.08.070; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Location Of Meetings: Every meeting of the council shall be held in the
city hall council chambers, unless the mayor or the council members calling a
regular or special meeting designate another place in the city for the holding
of the regular or special meeting; provided, that any adjourned meeting may be
held at any other place within the city designated by the council. (2002 Code §
2.08.080; amd. 2013 Code)
1-7-7: VACANCIES IN OFFICE:
   A.   When a vacancy occurs in the office of a municipal elected official,
except the mayor, the city council shall appoint, by a majority vote of the
remaining members, a person to fill the vacancy until the next general
municipal election and until a successor is elected and qualified. Any vacancy
shall then be filled at the next general municipal election by election of a
person to complete the balance of any unexpired term. If the vacancy has not
been filled within sixty (60) days after it occurs, the city council shall call
for a special election for the purpose of filling the vacancy for the duration
of the unexpired term. If a vacancy is not filled by the special election, it
should be filled by appointment as provided in this subsection.
   B.   When a majority of city council offices are vacant more than sixty (60)
days before the beginning of a regular filing period for general municipal
elections, the remaining members of the city council shall call for a special
election to be held in the city for the purpose of filling all vacant offices
for the remainder of their unexpired terms. For this purpose, the requirement
of a quorum may be waived. (2002 Code § 2.08.060; amd. 2013 Code)
1-7-8: AUTHORITY TO SECURE SERVICES:
   A.   The city is authorized to secure the services of the Oklahoma municipal
league and to be a member thereof. (2002 Code § 1.04.070)
   B.   The city council may provide for membership in, or secure the services
of, other organizations to the extent allowed in the annual budget. (2002 Code
§ 1.04.070; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 8
CITY MANAGER
SECTION:
1-8-1: Appointment; Qualifications; Restrictions
1-8-2: Duties
1-8-3: Acting City Manager
1-8-4: Suspension Or Removal Of City Manager And Acting City Manager
1-8-1: APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS; RESTRICTIONS:
The city council shall appoint a city manager for an indefinite term by a vote
of a majority of all its members. He or she shall be chosen solely on the basis
of his or her executive and administrative qualifications with special
reference to his or her actual experience in, or his or her knowledge of,
accepted practices in respect to the duties of his or her office. At the time
of his or her appointment, the city manager need not be a resident of the city
or state, but if not, he or she shall locate residence in the city during the
first year of his or her tenure and shall continue to reside within the city
for the remainder of his or her tenure. The city manager may appoint himself or
herself, or the council or other authority may appoint or elect him or her, to
other offices and positions in the city government, subject to regulations
prescribed by ordinance, but he or she may not receive compensation for service
in such other offices or positions. Neither the mayor nor any members of the
city council may be appointed city manager during the term for which he or she
shall have been elected nor within two (2) years after the expiration of his or
her term. (2002 Code § 2.12.010; amd. 2013 Code)
1-8-2: DUTIES:
The city manager shall be the chief executive officer and head of the
administrative branch of the city government. He or she shall execute the laws
and administer the government of the city and shall be responsible therefor to
the council. He or she shall:
   A.   Appoint and, when necessary for the good of the city, remove, demote,
lay off or suspend all heads of administrative departments and other
administrative officers and employees of the city except as otherwise provided
by law. The manager or the council, by ordinance, may authorize the head of a
department, office or agency to appoint and remove the subordinates in such
department, office or agency subject to the right of the city manager to
approve or reject the same;
   B.   Supervise and control all administrative departments, officers and
agencies;
   C.   Prepare a budget annually and submit it to the city council and be
responsible for the administration of the budget after it goes into effect; and
recommend to the council any changes in the budget which he or she deems
desirable;
   D.   Submit to the council a report after the end of each fiscal year on the
finances and administrative activities of the city for the preceding year;
   E.   Keep the council advised of the financial condition and future needs of
the city, and make recommendations as he or she deems necessary or appropriate;
and
   F.   Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by law or by ordinance.
(2002 Code § 2.12.020; amd. 2013 Code)
1-8-3: ACTING CITY MANAGER:
The city manager, by letter filed with the city clerk, may appoint a qualified
administrative officer of the city to be acting city manager during the
temporary absence or disability of the city manager. The council may appoint an
acting city manager whenever:
   A.   The city manager fails to make such designation;
   B.   The council suspends the city manager; or
   C.   There is a vacancy in the office of city manager. (2002 Code §
2.12.030)
1-8-4: SUSPENSION OR REMOVAL OF CITY MANAGER AND ACTING CITY MANAGER:
The council may suspend or remove the city manager or acting city manager at
any time by a vote of a majority of all its members. (2002 Code § 2.12.040)
CHAPTER 9
CITY DEPARTMENTS
ARTICLE A. CITY CLERK DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-9A-1: Office Created; Appointment And Term
1-9A-2: Duties
1-9A-3: Compensation
1-9A-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
The city clerk shall be an officer of the city, appointed by the city manager
for an indefinite term. (2013 Code)
1-9A-2: DUTIES:
   A.   Subject to such regulations and policies as may be established by the
city council or the city manager, the city clerk shall:
      1.   Serve as clerk for the city council, to include keeping a record of
minutes and documentation of actions taken;
      2.   Keep a journal of the proceedings of the city council;
      3.   Enroll all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council in
a book or set of books kept for that purpose;
      4.   Act as the designated custodian of records for all administrative
records as set out more completely in chapter 12 of this title, including the
keeping of such archives and official sealed documents as required by law or
ordinance;
      5.   Attest and affix the seal of the city to documents as required by
law or ordinance; and
      6.   Have such other powers, duties and functions related to his or her
statutory duties as may be prescribed by law, ordinance or directive.
   B.   The person who serves as city clerk may be employed or assigned by the
city to perform duties not related to the position of city clerk. The salary,
if any, for such additional duties shall be provided for separately within the
annual municipal budget ordinance. (2013 Code)
1-9A-3: COMPENSATION:
Compensation for the position of city clerk shall be designated within the
annual municipal budget ordinance. (2013 Code)
ARTICLE B. FINANCE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-9B-1: Finance Director
1-9B-2: City Treasurer
1-9B-1: FINANCE DIRECTOR:
The finance director shall be an officer of the city appointed by the city
manager for an indefinite term. The finance director shall have supervision and
control of the department of finance. (2013 Code)
1-9B-2: CITY TREASURER:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment And Term: The city treasurer shall be an
officer of the city, appointed by the city council for an indefinite term. The
same person may hold the offices of city clerk and city treasurer.
   B.   Duties:
      1.   Subject to such regulations and policies as may be established by
the city council or the city manager, the city treasurer shall:
         a.   Deposit daily funds received for the city in such depositories as
the city council may designate;
         b.   Cooperate with the city manager and the city council in the
process of creating the annual municipal budget;
         c.   Keep one or more accounts accurately reflecting all city revenues
and expenditures;
         d.   Keep one or more accounts accurately reflecting all trust
authority revenues and expenditures;
         e.   Ensure the timely payment of all city payroll, tax and debt
obligations; and
         f.   Have such other powers, duties and functions related to his or
her statutory duties as may be prescribed by law, ordinance or directive.
      2.   The person who serves as city treasurer may be employed by the city
to perform duties not related to the position of city treasurer.
   C.   Compensation: Compensation for the position of city treasurer shall be
designated within the annual municipal budget. The salary, if any, for such
additional duties as are authorized by subsection B2 of this section shall
likewise be provided for separately within the annual municipal budget. (Ord.
703, 7-20-2015)
ARTICLE C. LEGAL DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-9C-1: Established; Appointment, Removal And Qualifications Of City Attorney
1-9C-2: Duties Of City Attorney
1-9C-1: ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT, REMOVAL AND QUALIFICATIONS OF CITY ATTORNEY:
There shall be a legal department, the head of which is the city attorney who
shall be appointed by, and shall report to, the city manager for an indefinite
term. Removal of the city attorney shall be at the discretion of the city
manager, subject to city personnel policies governing the termination of city
employees generally. The city attorney is an officer of the city and has
supervision and control of the legal department. The city attorney shall be an
attorney licensed by the Oklahoma Bar Association. (Ord. 519, 7-8-2004; amd.
2013 Code)
1-9C-2: DUTIES OF CITY ATTORNEY:
The city attorney is the chief legal adviser of the city council and all other
officers, departments, and agencies of the city in matters relating to their
official powers and duties. He or she is the prosecuting officer for the city
in municipal court and represents the city in proceedings in the civil courts
and performs all services incident to his or her position which may be required
by law or ordinance. (2002 Code § 2.24.020; amd. 2013 Code)
ARTICLE D. POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-9D-1: Established; Chief Of Police
1-9D-2: Duties Of Police Officers
1-9D-3: Police Officer Hiring Requirements
1-9D-4: Bylaws
1-9D-5: Volunteer And Reserve Officers
1-9D-5-1: Police Reserve Force
1-9D-1: ESTABLISHED; CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Department Established; Appointment And Removal Of Chief: There shall
be a police department, the head of which is the chief of police who shall be
appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and removable by the city
manager. (2002 Code § 2.40.010)
   B.   Powers And Duties: The chief of police is an officer of the city and
has supervision and control of the police department. The chief of police shall
enforce the municipal ordinances and shall have such other powers, duties and
functions as may be prescribed by law or ordinance. (2002 Code § 2.40.010; amd.
2013 Code)
   C.   Qualifications:
      1.   Any person appointed to the position of chief of police shall meet
the following qualifications:
         a.   Be at least twenty one (21) years of age;
         b.   Be a citizen of the United States;
         c.   Possess at least a high school diploma or general education
diploma (GED);
         d.   Be certified as a peace officer in this state by the council on
law enforcement education and training (CLEET), or meet all requirements
necessary for CLEET certification and obtain such certification within six (6)
months of assuming the position of chief of police or as otherwise allowed by
70 Oklahoma Statutes chapter 50, section 3311; and
         e.   Have successfully completed a course of training meeting at least
the minimal criteria established by CLEET for police chief administration,
successfully completed an approved police chief administrative school approved
CLEET, or successfully complete such course of training or school within twelve
(12) months of assuming the position of chief of police.
      2.   a. Any person who does not meet the qualifications of subsection C1d
or C1e of this section at the time of appointment to the position of chief of
police and who fails, after assuming the position of chief of police, to meet
such qualifications within the time required shall be removed from the
position.
         b.   Any person assuming the position of chief of police without prior
CLEET certification who fails to complete an approved course of training or
police chief administration school within the time required shall be precluded
from obtaining CLEET certification while in such position.
         c.   CLEET shall establish minimal criteria for the qualifications of
subsection C1e of this section relating to a course of training and police
chief administration schools and approve all training offered in this state
relating to police administration. (2013 Code)
1-9D-2: DUTIES OF POLICE OFFICERS:
   A.   In accordance with state law, a police officer of the city is defined
as a full time duly appointed (temporary or permanent) officer who is paid for
working more than twenty five (25) hours per week and whose duties are to
preserve the public peace; protect life and property; prevent crime; apprehend
and arrest on view, on verified complaint or on warrant, the perpetrators of
crime and deliver them to proper authorities; serve warrants, writs and
executions; suppress unlawful assembly; and enforce laws and ordinances of the
state and city. (2013 Code)
   B.   All police officers are officers of the city. (2002 Code § 2.40.010)
   C.   The police department has charge of and operates the city jail. (2002
Code § 2.40.020; amd. 2013 Code)
1-9D-3: POLICE OFFICER HIRING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Minimum qualifications for a person to be appointed or retained, as
applicable, as a temporary police officer in the city include the following:
      1.   Such person has attained twenty one (21) years of age prior to
certification as a peace officer and may not be more than forty five (45) years
of age at the time of hire.
      2.   Such person must possess a high school diploma or a GED equivalency
certificate (preference may be shown to candidates with advanced education, but
such is not required).
      3.   Such person has provided proof of United States citizenship or
resident alien status, pursuant to an employment eligibility verification form
from the United States citizenship and immigration services.
      4.   The Oklahoma state bureau of investigation and the federal bureau of
investigation must report that such person has no record of conviction for a
felony, crime involving moral turpitude or crime of domestic violence; and is
not participating in a deferred sentence agreement for any of such offenses.
      5.   Such person shall give consent to undergo a preemployment drug
screen. Positive testing with respect to any illegal substance will result in
immediate termination of the hiring process or of temporary employment status,
as applicable.
      6.   Such person's driving record shall disclose a valid Oklahoma
driver's license; no more than two (2) moving violations within the most recent
three (3) years; no more than one at fault traffic accident within the most
recent three (3) years; and no DWI, DUI or reckless driving violation within
the past five (5) years.
      7.   Such person must certify that he or she is physically capable of
fully participating in and will complete all phases of the council on law
enforcement education and training (CLEET) basic peace officer certification
academy.
   B.   No temporary police officer shall receive a permanent appointment
unless and until:
      1.   Pursuant to state law, the city has administered an evaluation using
a psychological instrument approved by CLEET. The city shall administer this
evaluation in accordance with standards established within the test document. A
psychologist of the candidate's choice and at the candidate's expense, provided
the psychologist is licensed by the state of Oklahoma, shall interpret the test
results. The city shall provide the psychologist a statement confirming the
identity of the individual taking the test as the person who is employed or
seeking to be employed as a police officer and attesting that it administered
the evaluation as required. The psychologist shall certify whether the employee
is suitable to serve as a police officer. Any person found to be unsuitable for
permanent appointment as a police officer shall be ineligible for
reconsideration for a minimum of one year.
      2.   Such temporary police officer shall, within no more than six (6)
months from the date of appointment as a temporary police officer, successfully
complete all phases of the CLEET basic peace officer certification academy. Any
person failing to meet this requirement shall be immediately terminated from
employment unless CLEET determines there is good cause for an extension of the
time requirement.
      3.   Following certification by CLEET, such temporary police officer must
satisfactorily complete a ten (10) week field training program with a field
training officer.
      4.   Following all foregoing requirements for permanent appointment as a
police officer in the city, the officer will be placed on the same one year
probationary period applicable to all city employees. (2013 Code)
   C.   Every person who is employed as a permanent police officer prior to
July 1, 1968, or is retired under 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 50-114, shall
enjoy the privilege of certification as afforded by this section. (2002 Code §
2.40.030; amd. 2013 Code)
1-9D-4: BYLAWS:
   A.   All police officers are required, when notified, to respond to alarms
and emergencies.
   B.   Unless excused by the chief of police, they are required to be present
at all regular meetings, special meetings, and special schools and seminars
presented for the benefit of police officers.
   C.   The police department shall have at least one regular department
meeting each month.
   D.   Any regular police officer or reserve police officer having two (2)
unexcused absences in succession or three (3) unexcused absences in a period of
three (3) months will be discharged from the police department as a full time
officer or as a reserve officer.
   E.   All reserve police officers leaving the city for an extended period of
time will be required to notify the chief of police.
   F.   Any reserve police officer refusing to attend training classes provided
for him or her will be terminated.
   G.   Any reserve member of the police department shall be dropped from the
rolls for any of the following offenses:
      1.   Conduct unbecoming a police officer.
      2.   Any act of insubordination.
      3.   Neglect of duty.
      4.   Any violation of rules and regulations governing the police
department.
      5.   Conviction of a felony, a crime involving moral turpitude, or a
crime of domestic violence. (2002 Code § 2.40.020; amd. 2013 Code)
1-9D-5: VOLUNTEER AND RESERVE OFFICERS:
The police department may use reserve officers as provided in the city
council's annual budget. The chief of police shall propose rules and
regulations for the organization and use of said volunteers or reserves as may
be approved by the city council. (2002 Code § 2.40.040)
1-9D-5-1: POLICE RESERVE FORCE:
   A.   Established: There is established a police reserve force for the city.
   B.   Appointment: Members of the police reserve force shall be appointed or
relieved and serve at the discretion of the chief of police, with the consent
and approval of the city manager, and shall serve as police officers during the
actual discharge of official duties only. (2002 Code § 2.40.040)
   C.   Call To Active Duty: Members of the police reserve force may be called
into active service at any time the chief of police considers it necessary to
have additional police officers to preserve the peace and enforce the law.
While upon active duty, the members of the police reserve force are authorized
to make arrests for violation of the ordinances, laws and regulations of the
city and the state.
   D.   Compensation: Members of the police reserve force of the city shall
serve without compensation and shall not be considered members of the regular
city police department and shall not, under any conditions, become eligible for
a pension and retirement fund of the city. Noncompensated reserve officers may
serve as dispatchers or confinement officers at the city jail.
   E.   Training, Qualifications And Standards: Reserve police officers shall
be trained in accordance with 70 Oklahoma Statutes chapter 50, section 3311.
The chief of police may establish additional training requirements,
qualifications and standards for members of the police reserve force and shall
establish rules and regulations governing reserve police officers. The city
manager may establish minimum standards for reserve officers as used by the
regular police department. (2002 Code § 2.40.040; amd. 2013 Code)
ARTICLE E. FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-9E-1: Established; Employment Requirements
1-9E-2: Duties Of Department Members
1-9E-3: Powers And Duties Of Chief
1-9E-4: Composition Of Department
1-9E-5: New Members
1-9E-6: Volunteers/Reserves
1-9E-7: Control At Fires
1-9E-8: Inspections
1-9E-9: Right Of Way
1-9E-10: Service Outside City Limits
1-9E-11: Regulations
1-9E-12: Inspection, Testing And Maintenance Reports
1-9E-1: ESTABLISHED; EMPLOYMENT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   There shall be a fire department, the head of which is the chief of the
fire department, or fire chief, appointed by the city manager for an indefinite
term, and removable by the city manager. The chief of the fire department is an
officer of the city and has supervision and control of the fire department.
(2002 Code § 2.44.010)
   B.   Employment and promotions in the fire department will be based, in
part, on the ability to successfully complete and qualify on an objective
recognized test. (2002 Code § 2.44.010; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Employment qualifications for firefighters are as follows:
      1.   Must be between twenty one (21) and forty five (45) years of age.
      2.   Must be a high school graduate or have a GED certificate. (2002 Code
§ 2.44.010)
      3.   Must have or be able to qualify for a commercial operator's or
driver's license. (2002 Code § 2.44.010; amd. 2013 Code)
      4.   Must be able to pass a physical examination (city's choice of
doctor).
      5.   Must have an insurable driving record. (2002 Code § 2.44.010)
1-9E-2: DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
It is the duty of the fire department, among others, to extinguish fires; to
rescue persons endangered by fire; to resuscitate and to administer first aid
to persons injured in or about burning structures, or elsewhere, in case of an
emergency; to promote fire prevention; and, unless otherwise provided, to
enforce all ordinances relating to fires, fire prevention, and safety of
persons from fire, explosions and other emergency situations. (2002 Code §
2.44.020; amd. 2013 Code)
1-9E-3: POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF:
   A.   The chief, as head of the department, shall be subject to the laws of
the state of Oklahoma, ordinances of the city, and the rules and regulations
herein adopted.
   B.   The chief shall be held responsible for the general condition and
efficient operation of the department, the training of members, and the
performance of all other duties imposed upon him or her. (2002 Code § 2.44.030)
   C.   The chief shall inspect, or cause to be inspected by members of the
department, the fire hydrants, cisterns and other sources of water supply in
the city at least twice per year. (2002 Code § 2.44.030; amd. 2013 Code)
   D.   The chief shall maintain a library or file of publications on fire
prevention and fire protection and shall make use of said publications to the
best advantage of all members.
   E.   The chief shall make every effort to attend all fires and direct the
officers and members in the performance of their duties.
   F.   The chief shall see that citizens are kept informed on fire hazards in
the community and on the activities of the department.
   G.   The chief shall see that each fire is carefully investigated to
determine its cause and, in the case of suspicion of incendiarism, shall notify
proper authorities and secure and preserve all possible evidence for future use
in the case.
   H.   The chief shall keep the council informed regarding the fire department
and its needs, and shall make such reports as the council and city manager may
require. (2002 Code § 2.44.030)
   I.   The chief shall see that complete records are kept of all fires,
inspections, apparatus and equipment, personnel, and other information about
the work of the department, and shall make such reports as the city manager and
council may require. (2002 Code § 2.44.060)
1-9E-4: COMPOSITION OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Deputy Chief: The deputy chief(s) shall be selected upon his or her
ability to meet the following requirements: (2002 Code § 2.44.090; amd. 2013
Code)
      1.   Knowledge of firefighting.
      2.   Ability to lead people.
      3.   Knowledge of firefighting equipment. (2002 Code § 2.44.090)
   B.   Company Officers: The company officers shall be selected upon their
ability to meet the following requirements:
      1.   Knowledge of firefighting.
      2.   Ability to lead people.
      3.   Knowledge of firefighting equipment.
      4.   Performance on an objective test. (2002 Code § 2.44.100)
1-9E-5: NEW MEMBERS:
   A.   Testing Fee: There is hereby established a testing fee to be included
with the application forms for the new firefighters. The purpose of the fee is
to cover the expenses of testing materials and evaluation of new candidates.
The amount of the fee is established by the city council. (Ord. 569, 5-7-2007;
amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Probationary Period: All new members shall be on probation for one year
after their appointment. (2002 Code § 2.44.120)
1-9E-6: VOLUNTEERS/RESERVES:
The fire department may use reserve firefighters as provided in the city
council's annual budget. The fire chief shall propose rules and regulations for
the organization and use of said volunteers as may be approved by the city
council. The rules of the department shall include: (2002 Code § 2.44.130)
   A.   The fire department includes volunteer firefighters. It shall include
not less than twelve (12) nor more than twenty five (25) volunteer
firefighters.
   B.   For the purpose of this chapter, a volunteer firefighter shall be
considered one who is enrolled as a member of the fire department and who
serves in that capacity without receiving a regular salary, but receiving an
amount per call as established by the city council in which he or she
participates. (2002 Code § 2.44.130; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   All volunteer firefighters are required, when notified, to respond to
alarms of fire and other emergencies.
   D.   All volunteer firefighters are required to be present at all regular
meetings, call meetings and schools presented for the benefit of the
firefighters.
   E.   There shall be at least one regular business meeting each month.
   F.   Any volunteer firefighter having two (2) unexcused absences in
succession or three (3) unexcused absences in a period of three (3) months will
be dropped from the fire department rolls.
   G.   Volunteer firefighters leaving town for an extended period of time will
be required to notify the chief. (2002 Code § 2.44.130)
   H.   Any volunteer firefighter refusing to attend training classes provided
for him or her will be discharged.
   I.   Any volunteer member of the fire department shall be discharged from
the rolls for the following offenses: (2002 Code § 2.44.130; amd. 2013 Code)
      1.   Any act of insubordination.
      2.   Conduct unbecoming a firefighter.
      3.   Any violation of rules and regulations governing the fire
department.
      4.   Neglect of duty.
      5.   Conviction of a felony. (2002 Code § 2.44.130)
1-9E-7: CONTROL AT FIRES:
The chief of the fire department or the person acting in his or her absence
shall have full power, control, and command over all persons whomsoever present
at all fires, and he or she shall direct the use of all fire apparatus and
equipment, and command all firefighters in the discharge of their duties. He or
she shall take such measures as may be necessary in the preservation and
protection of persons and property and the extinguishing of fires. (2002 Code §
2.44.070; amd. 2013 Code)
1-9E-8: INSPECTIONS:
The chief is empowered to enter any and all buildings and premises at any
reasonable hour for the purpose of making inspections and to serve written
notice upon the owner or occupant to abate, within a specified time, any and
all fire hazards that may be found. Any person so served with a notice to abate
any fire hazard or hazards shall comply therewith and promptly notify the
chief. (2002 Code § 2.44.050)
1-9E-9: RIGHT OF WAY:
All motor equipment of fire department members shall have the right of way over
all other traffic when responding to an alarm. (2002 Code § 2.44.080)
1-9E-10: SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS:
   A.   Charges:
      1.   Any contract entered into by the city with an individual owner,
firm, private corporation or association to provide fire protection outside the
corporate limits of the city shall provide for the payment therefor by the
owner, firm, private corporation, or association to the city in amount(s) to be
established by the city council.
      2.   The total amount chargeable to such owner, firm, private corporation
or association for services provided pursuant to a contract provided by
subsection A1 of this section shall be certified by a bill of costs presented
to the city clerk by the chief. The city clerk shall add any other applicable
costs and deliver an invoice for the total amount to such owner, firm, private
corporation or association. The total amount on the invoice shall be paid to
the city clerk, and the total amount so paid shall be credited to the general
fund of the city. (2002 Code § 2.44.140; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Authority To Dispatch Equipment: Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit
the chief of the fire department, or his or her deputy on duty, from
dispatching fire or other emergency equipment outside the corporate limits of
the city as deemed necessary and appropriate. (2002 Code § 2.44.150; amd. 2013
Code)
1-9E-11: REGULATIONS:
The mayor and city council, by motion or resolution, may adopt and change
regulations relating to the fire department, its organization, and operation.
The chief may recommend such regulations and changes therein to the city
manager and city council any time. (2002 Code § 2.44.040)
1-9E-12: INSPECTION, TESTING AND MAINTENANCE REPORTS:
All inspection, testing and maintenance reports related to fire suppression,
fire detection and life safety equipment systems that are required to be
furnished to the fire department by the fire code shall be electronically
forwarded to the fire department using the City’s approved online system for
inspection, testing and maintenance reporting. Any company doing work on fire
suppression, fire detection and life safety equipment systems installed in
structures within the City shall be required to register with the City’s
approved online reporting system and pay any fees assessed in connection with
the submission of inspection and maintenance reports. Reports furnished in a
manner that does not comply with the provisions of this subsection shall result
in the system being deemed non-compliant with the provisions of this Chapter.
(Ord. 826, 4-7-2025)
ARTICLE F. PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-9F-1: Established; Composition
1-9F-2: Divisions
1-9F-3: Duties
1-9F-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
There shall be a public works department, the head of which shall be the
director of public works. The city manager or, if on staff, the director of
community development shall be ex officio director of public works unless he or
she appoints another to be director of public works. The director is an officer
of the city and has supervision and control of the public works department.
(2002 Code § 2.52.010; amd. 2013 Code)
1-9F-2: DIVISIONS:
There shall be such divisions within the public works department as the city
manager or the city council may create, with such appropriate titles and with
such powers and duties of the department as may be assigned to the respective
divisions. The head of a division may have an appropriate title such as chief,
superintendent, manager, etc. (2002 Code § 2.52.020; amd. 2013 Code)
1-9F-3: DUTIES:
The public works department shall have the following duties insofar as the city
performs these functions by its own forces (and not by contract or other
delegation):
   A.   To improve, maintain and clean streets (including alleys and other
public ways), bridges and sidewalks, and traffic control signs, markings,
signals and devices; to erect and maintain street name signs; and to supervise
the use of rights of way by privately owned utilities.
   B.   To improve, maintain and operate the water system and the storm and
sanitary sewer systems.
   C.   To maintain and operate all parks, playgrounds, swimming pools and
other recreational facilities and programs operated by the city.
   D.   To maintain and operate any cemetery owned or administered by the city.
   E.   To perform such other functions relating to the construction,
maintenance, repair, improvement and operation of the physical facilities owned
or used by the city government as the city manager may prescribe consistent
with laws and ordinances.
   F.   To enforce, upon adoption by the city council of ordinances referring
to specifications or standards pertaining to matters which the city has the
power to regulate, such specifications and guidelines as may be necessary in
the construction, improvement and maintenance of buildings, sewers, water
lines, streets, sidewalks, and their appurtenances or other public works within
the city.
   G.   To collect and dispose of garbage and other refuse as provided by this
code, or to contract with a private firm to perform such duties. (2002 Code §
2.52.020; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 10
CITY OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
SECTION:
1-10-1: Number And Classes Of Officers And Employees; Compensation
1-10-2: Bond Requirements
1-10-3: Succession In Emergencies
1-10-4: Appointments, Suspensions And Removals
1-10-5: Employee Handbook And Personnel Policies Adopted
1-10-1: NUMBER AND CLASSES OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES; COMPENSATION:
   A.   The city council, by motion, resolution or ordinance, may regulate the
number and classes of offices and positions of employment in the various
departments, offices and agencies of the city, and may determine or regulate
the compensation to be paid to officers and employees. Compensation not
otherwise provided for shall be at the prevailing minimum wage rate. (2002 Code
§ 2.32.010)
   B.   Neither the municipal judge nor any other officer or employee of the
city may receive as compensation any fee of any kind except as may be
specifically provided by ordinance; and all fees and other monies collected for
the city by an officer or employee shall be paid to the city clerk or his or
her designee to be deposited as provided by law. (2002 Code § 2.32.010; amd.
2013 Code)
1-10-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Before entering upon their official duties, and in no case later than
ten (10) days after appointment, the following officers of the city shall
provide bonds for the faithful performance of their official duties, payable to
the city, with a surety company authorized to operate within the state, in the
amounts respectively indicated after their titles:
 
City Officer                                                     Bond Amount
City manager                                                     $ 5,000.00
City clerk                                                       50,000.00
City treasurer                                                   50,000.00
City clerk and city treasurer in case the same person holds both 75,000.00
offices
Utility billing clerk                                            5,000.00
Municipal court clerk (see also subsection                       5,000.00
1-11-7B of this title)
 
   B.   The city council may, by motion or resolution, require other officers
and employees in such positions as it may designate to be bonded in such
amounts as it determines. The city council may also, by motion or resolution,
increase the amount of the bonds for the personnel listed in subsection A of
this section and may also provide for blanket bonds for city personnel. The
city shall pay the premiums on such bonds. (2002 Code § 2.32.020; amd. 2013
Code)
1-10-3: SUCCESSION IN EMERGENCIES:
The line of succession to be used in establishing the government head of the
city, in the event of an emergency or disaster that incapacitates one or more
officers, shall be as follows:
