occupant of any premises on which a domesticated animal remains, or to which it
customarily returns, for a period of ten (10) days or more, shall be deemed to
be harboring or keeping the animal, whether or not such occupant is licensed or
otherwise identified as such.
PERSON: Any living human being, estate, association, trust or any legally
fictitious person, such as a sole proprietor, corporation, limited liability
company or other entity.
SANITARY: A condition of sufficiently good order and cleanliness to effectively
preclude the probability of disease transmission.
SWINE: Any hog, pig, boar or other animal of the Suidae family, except a
miniature pig that has been licensed as provided by this chapter.
UNDER LEASH: Refers to an animal that is securely held, restrained and confined
by its owner or other person designated by its owner, by means of a strap,
chain, rope, cord or other device not exceeding eight feet (8') in length, and
in such manner as to prevent the animal from attacking any person.
VICIOUS ANIMAL: A dangerous animal, as further provided by section
6-6A-9 of this chapter, that has bitten, or has attacked with the apparent
intent to bite, any human being or any domestic animal belonging to a person
other than the owner of the dangerous animal without undue provocation for a
second or more time. A vicious animal may be subject to impoundment, adoption
outside the city limits or euthanasia, as determined to be in the public
interest by the municipal court, other lawful authority or the animal control
officer, and its owner may be subject to civil penalties if such dangerous
animal was at large at the time of such second or more incident.
WILD ANIMALS: Those that possess an erratic or violent nature or disposition so
as to require confinement and subjugation to avoid escape and/or injury to
humans. Examples include bees, feral hogs, monkeys and rats. (Ord. 641, 10-25-
2010; amd. Ord. 657, 3-5-2012)
6-6-2: ZONING REGULATIONS TO PREVAIL:
In case of any conflict between this chapter and the current or any future
zoning ordinance, the provision(s) of the zoning ordinance shall control and
shall supersede the provision(s) of this chapter. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6-3: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter expressly do not apply to laboratories, rescue
services, pet stores and veterinarian hospitals except to the extent made
applicable by ordinances pertaining to the licensure of businesses within the
city. (Ord. 657, 3-5-2012)
6-6-4: ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
   A.   Designated:
      1.   The police department shall be responsible for the enforcement of
all provisions of this chapter and all matters related to the keeping and
control of animals.
      2.   The police department shall designate one or more of its employees
as the animal control officer(s).
   B.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The animal control officer is authorized to pick up and impound all
animals that are in violation of any provision of this chapter and/or cite the
owner of such animal for any corresponding violation.
      2.   The animal control officer shall impound all animals lawfully
detained or captured and shall provide suitable and necessary sustenance and
water, and shall otherwise treat them in a humane manner.
      3.   The animal control officer shall not release an impounded animal to
its owner or any person until all impoundment fees and any related charges are
paid in full. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6-5: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
   A.   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or who violates
or refuses or neglects to carry out any reasonable order made by the animal
control officer or other lawful authority pursuant to this chapter, shall, upon
conviction, be guilty of an offense punishable by as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code and as set forth in the municipal bond schedule adopted by
the governing body as provided in section
1-11-19 of this code. Each day upon which any violation continues shall be
deemed a separate offense.
   B.   There shall be assessed against any animal owner a sixty dollar
($60.00) cost of capture for apprehending any animal at large. There shall also
be assessed a five dollar ($5.00) per day poundage fee against any owner whose
animal is apprehended as an animal at large. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010; amd. 2013
Code)
ARTICLE A. GENERAL ANIMAL CONTROL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
6-6A-1: Number Of Animals
6-6A-2: Animals At Large
6-6A-3: Turning Animals At Large
6-6A-4: Pasturing In Public
6-6A-5: Livestock
6-6A-6: Hobby Chickens
6-6A-7: Nuisance Animals
6-6A-8: Dangerous Animals
6-6A-9: Vicious Animals
6-6A-10: Houses And Premises
6-6A-11: Diseased, Injured, Dead Animals
6-6A-12: Treatment Of Animals
6-6A-13: Itinerant Peddling Of Animals Prohibited
6-6A-14: Additional Prohibitions
6-6A-15: Hobbyist Exemption Permit
6-6A-16: Kennel Proprietors
6-6A-1: NUMBER OF ANIMALS:
It is unlawful for any person, other than a properly licensed kennel
proprietor, to keep or maintain or permit to be kept or maintained any
combination of more than three (3) otherwise permitted animals per household.
(Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-2: ANIMALS AT LARGE:
No owner shall permit any animal owned, harbored or kept by such person to be
at large at any time within the city. Failure of any owner to prevent any
animal from running or being "at large", as defined in this chapter, whether
such animal is licensed or unlicensed, is an offense under this chapter.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, however, it shall be permissible for a dog to be
let off the premises of its owner only when under leash; and it shall be
permissible for a police dog not to be under leash or obediently at heel while
being utilized as a police dog in the performance of police duty when
accompanied by a police officer. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-3: TURNING ANIMALS AT LARGE:
It is unlawful for any person to open any enclosure in which any animal is
confined so as to turn the animal at large, or in any other manner to turn an
animal at large. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-4: PASTURING IN PUBLIC:
It is unlawful for any person to stake, confine or pasture any animal on any
public school ground or other federal, state, city or other public property, on
any railroad right of way, or on any private property without the consent of
the person owning or controlling such property. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-5: LIVESTOCK:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection B of this section and section
6-6A-6 of this article, it is unlawful for any person to keep livestock within
the city limits other than in an enclosure awaiting immediate transportation
outside the city.
   B.   One cow, horse, Shetland pony, mule or goat may be kept in any pen,
lot, corral or similar enclosure of not less than one acre per such animal, up
to a maximum of two (2) such animals within the city; provided, that:
      1.   The number limitation shall not apply to agricultural districts in
the city where farming, dairy and ranching operations are allowed uses by
right. Livestock maintained in an agricultural district shall be subject to the
enclosure and space provisions of this section and all other laws or
regulations applicable to agricultural operations.
      2.   The owner or person in charge of such animal(s) shall provide fences
or barriers of such height and sufficient strength as may be necessary to
prevent the escape of such animal(s) from such pen, lot, corral or other
enclosure.
      3.   The owner or person in charge of the premises upon which an animal
is permitted to be kept by the provisions of this section, and which is penned
or confined thereon, must maintain such premises in a sanitary condition not
offensive or dangerous to the public, and must clean or cause to be cleaned
each day the premises, and remove and dispose of all trash, refuse, rubbish and
animal excrement, following each day an animal is kept, penned or contained in
or upon such premises.
      4.   No person shall allow such an animal to produce noise loud enough to
disturb the peace of persons of reasonable sensitivity, and it is hereby
declared a nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person to allow such
nuisance to exist. (Ord. 657, 3-5-2012)
      5.   All persons intending to keep livestock pursuant to this section
shall register them with the animal control officer on a form to be provided by
the police department prior to acquiring the livestock. The registration
process shall include an inspection of the premises to ensure compliance with
this section. The fee to be charged for registration shall be established by
the city council. (Ord. 657, 3-5-2012; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   No livestock of any description shall be permitted in multi-family
housing, to include duplexes.
   D.   This section shall not be construed so as to permit the slaughter of
livestock within city limits under any circumstance, except as allowed as of
right in an agricultural zone.
   E.   Additional sanitation standards are as follows:
      1.   An approved insecticide shall be used as often as recommended by the
manufacturer and as often as needed to prevent infestation.
      2.   It is unlawful to dump or place any manure or other wastes from such
pens or enclosures in garbage cans serviced by the city, or contract haulers
authorized by the city.
      3.   Exterior limits of animal or fowl enclosures shall be at least fifty
feet (50') from any private water well.
   F.   It is unlawful for any person to tether livestock for grazing or any
other purpose on any road or street right of way within the city. (Ord. 657, 3-
5-2012)
6-6A-6: HOBBY CHICKENS:
   A.   Except as provided in subsection 6-6A-5B of this article and as
permitted in accordance with this section, it is unlawful for any person to
keep livestock within the city limits other than in an enclosure awaiting
immediate transportation outside the city. This exception pertains only to
"hobby chickens" as defined in section
6-6-1 of this chapter. Roosters are expressly excluded from this exception and
are not permitted within city limits, except where permitted as of right in an
agriculture district. (Ord. 657, 3-5-2012)
   B.   All persons intending to keep hobby chickens shall register them with
the animal control officer on a form to be provided by the police department
prior to acquiring the chickens. The registration process shall include an
inspection of the premises to ensure compliance with this section. The fee to
be charged for registration shall be established by the city council. (Ord.
657, 3-5-2012; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   No hobby chickens shall be permitted in multi-family housing, to
include duplexes.
   D.   This section shall not be construed so as to permit the slaughter of
chickens within city limits under any circumstance, except as allowed as of
right in an agricultural zone.
   E.   In nonagricultural zones of the city, no more than five (5) hobby
chickens may be kept per residential lot.
   F.   No person shall allow such hobby chickens to produce noise loud enough
to disturb the peace of persons of reasonable sensitivity, and it is hereby
declared a nuisance and it shall be unlawful for any person to allow such
nuisance to exist.
   G.   Every keeper of hobby chickens shall observe the following practices:
      1.   Space:
         a.   Hobby chickens may not be kept on any parcel of land containing
less than two thousand (2,000) square feet in area. (Ord. 657, 3-5-2012)
         b.   Such hobby chickens shall be confined in an enclosure, provided
such enclosure prevents the fowl from being quartered within fifty feet (50')
of the exterior limits of a church, school, business or residence other than
the residence of the owner of the hobby chickens. (Ord. 657, 3-5-2012; amd.
2013 Code)
         c.   It is unlawful for any person to confine any such hobby chickens
unless provisions are made by such person for the proper feeding and the
furnishing of water at intervals not longer than twelve (12) hours.
      2.   Maintenance Of Enclosure:
         a.   Every keeper of hobby chickens shall confine the same in an
enclosure sufficient to prevent their running at large.
         b.   Such enclosure shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary
condition at all times.
         c.   An approved insecticide shall be used as often as recommended by
the manufacturer and as often as needed to prevent infestation.
         d.   No person shall impound any hobby chicken in a crate, box or
other enclosure, which crate, box or other enclosure does not permit each bird
so impounded to stand in a naturally erect position and make normal postural
adjustments.
      3.   Shelter And Drainage: Every keeper of hobby chickens shall provide
shelter or area of a size sufficient to be conducive to good sanitation
practices and shall provide adequate and sanitary drainage for the shelter or
area.
      4.   Disposal Of Litter And Droppings:
         a.   Every keeper of hobby chickens shall cause the litter and
droppings therefrom to be collected daily in a container or receptacle of such
type that, when closed, is ratproof and flytight and, after each such
collection, shall cause such container or receptacle to be kept closed.
         b.   At least twice each week, each such keeper shall cause all litter
and droppings so collected to be disposed of in a way as not to permit the
presence of fly larvae.
      5.   Storage Of Feed: Every keeper of hobby chickens shall cause all feed
provided therefor to be stored and kept in a ratproof, flytight building, box,
container or receptacle.
      6.   Inspection: The premises where hobby chickens are kept shall be
subject to inspection by the animal control officer at any reasonable hour of
the day. (Ord. 657, 3-5-2012)
6-6A-7: NUISANCE ANIMALS:
   A.   Nuisance Conditions: It is unlawful for any person to keep or harbor
within the city any "nuisance animal", as defined in section
6-6-1 of this chapter. Nuisance animal includes, without limitation, any dog,
cat or other animal that:
      1.   Habitually barks, howls, wails, or emits or utters sounds or loud
and disturbing noises which can be heard beyond the premises of the owner for a
sustained continuous period of ten (10) minutes or a cumulative period of
fifteen (15) minutes in any hour of the day or night or which otherwise cause
serious annoyance and disturb the peace or quietude of any person or persons,
other than the owner, within the vicinity of the place where same is being kept
or to the surrounding neighborhood;
      2.   Scratches or digs into any flowerbed, garden, tilled soil, shrubbery
or small plants and, in so doing, injures the same;
      3.   Habitually prowls around or over any premises not the property of
its owner, to the annoyance of the owner or occupant of such premises;
      4.   Overturns any garbage can or other vessel for waste products, or
scatters the contents of same;
      5.   Chases or kills any chicken or other domestic fowl;
      6.   Chases vehicles; or
      7.   Habitually runs at large.
   B.   Enforcement: It is the duty of the animal control officer or person
designated by him or her, upon being notified that any person has filed a
verified complaint alleging that an animal is a nuisance within the meaning of
this section, and upon concurrence by such authority that such animal is a
nuisance, to seize and impound the animal therein described until the soonest
available session of the municipal court. In the discretion of the animal
control officer, if there are circumstances such that the animal control
officer reasonably concludes that the animal presents no risk of harm to
others, it may be released prior to such court date. If the municipal judge
shall find that no nuisance exists, he or she shall order that the animal be
surrendered to the owner. If the municipal judge shall find that the animal is
a nuisance, he or she shall order the owner of the animal to give a good and
sufficient bond in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), to be received
by the city clerk upon condition that such owner shall abate and prevent such
nuisance from recurrence. The municipal judge shall order the return of the
animal to its owner upon payment of such bond, written and signed acceptance of
such conditions and upon payment of all actual costs and poundage fees
specified in this chapter. No nuisance animal shall be returned to the owner if
the same is a vicious animal or in any event until the animal is registered and
licensed as required by this chapter. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-8: DANGEROUS ANIMALS:
   A.   Restrictions: It is unlawful for any person to keep or harbor within
the city any "dangerous animal", as defined in section
6-6-1 of this chapter, except in confinement or otherwise under the complete
control and domination of the owner and in compliance with conditions set forth
in this section.
   B.   Impoundment And Redemption: A dangerous animal may be subject to
impoundment and release to its owner, or to a person other than its owner, only
upon satisfaction of the following conditions: If the municipal judge shall
find that an animal is a dangerous animal, he or she shall order the owner of
the animal to give a good and sufficient bond in the amount of one hundred
dollars ($100.00), to be received by the city clerk upon condition that such
owner shall ensure that such animal is kept in confinement or otherwise under
the complete control and domination of the owner at all times. Any enclosure
must be posted in such a way as to clearly warn the public of the presence of a
dangerous animal. The owner shall also be required to present proof of
homeowners' liability insurance in the amount of at least fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000.00). The municipal judge shall order the return of the animal
to its owner upon payment of such bond, written and signed acceptance of such
conditions and payment of the poundage fees specified in this chapter. No
dangerous animal shall be returned to the owner if the same is a vicious animal
or in any event until the animal is registered and licensed as required by this
chapter.
   C.   Destruction Authorized: Notwithstanding any other provision of this
chapter, any person may kill an animal in self-defense or in defense of another
when the animal, without undue provocation, bites or attacks or attempts to
bite or attack either person in such manner that an ordinarily prudent person
would be led to believe that the person toward whom the animal's conduct is
directed is about to be bitten or otherwise physically harmed. (Ord. 641, 10-
25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
6-6A-9: VICIOUS ANIMALS:
   A.   Prohibited; Penalty: It is unlawful, under any circumstance, for any
person to keep or harbor within the city any "vicious animal", as defined in
section
6-6-1 of this chapter. Any person who is the owner of an animal determined to
be a vicious animal shall be subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
in the event that the animal was at large during the course of events leading
to the determination that the animal is a vicious animal.
   B.   Impoundment; Adoption Or Euthanasia; Costs: It is the duty of the
animal control officer or persons authorized by him or her to seize and impound
any animal found by him or her to be vicious and to cause proceedings to be
instituted before the municipal court against the owner of such animal for
violation of this chapter. If such seized and impounded animal shall have
bitten a human being or domestic animal not belonging to the owner of the
vicious animal two (2) or more times, or attacked a human or domestic animal
not belonging to the owner of the vicious animal two (2) or more times with
apparent intent to bite, before such seizure and impounding, then the municipal
judge shall order the animal control officer or person designated by him or her
to euthanize the vicious animal unless suitable adoption arrangements for the
animal, as provided by this chapter, may be made within three (3) days of such
order. In all cases, the owner of the vicious animal shall be liable for all
costs associated with seizure, impoundment, maintenance and euthanasia or
adoption, as applicable.
   C.   Destruction Authorized: Notwithstanding any other provision of this
chapter, any person may kill an animal in self-defense or in defense of another
when the animal, without undue provocation, bites or attacks or attempts to
bite or attack said person in such manner that an ordinarily prudent person
would be led to believe that the person toward whom the animal's conduct is
directed is about to be bitten or otherwise physically harmed. (Ord. 641, 10-
25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
6-6A-10: HOUSES AND PREMISES:
   A.   Construction And Condition:
      1.   Every stable, dog kennel, chicken coop or other similar structure
wherein animals are kept within the city shall be constructed of such material
and in such manner that it can be kept clean and sanitary at all times.
      2.   Every such stable, dog kennel, chicken coop or other similar
structure wherein animals are kept shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary
condition, devoid of rodents and vermin and free from objectionable odors.
   B.   Manure:
      1.   Every such stable, dog kennel, chicken coop or other similar
structure wherein animals are kept, if located within two hundred feet (200')
of any tenement or apartment house, hotel, restaurant, boarding house, retail
or wholesale food store, building used for educational, religious, or hospital
purposes or residence other than that occupied by the owner or occupant of the
premises upon which such animal is kept, shall be provided with a watertight
and flytight receptacle for manure, of such size as to hold all accumulations
of manure. The receptacle shall be emptied sufficiently often and in such
manner as to prevent it from being or becoming a nuisance, and shall be kept
covered at all times except when open during the deposit or removal of manure
or refuse. No manure shall be allowed to accumulate on such premises except in
the receptacle.
      2.   With respect to any such stable, dog kennel, chicken coop or other
similar structure wherein animals are kept, accumulated manure shall be hauled
outside the city in a manner which does not jeopardize the public health, or
else shall be spread evenly upon the ground and turned under at once or as soon
as the weather permits.
   C.   Location: No such stable, dog kennel, chicken coop or other similar
structure wherein animals are kept shall be maintained closer than one hundred
feet (100') to any tenement or apartment house, hotel, restaurant, boarding
house, retail or wholesale food store, building used for educational,
religious, or hospital purposes, or residence other than that occupied by the
owner or occupant of the premises upon which such structure is kept.
   D.   Public View Of Breeding Prohibited: It is unlawful for any person to
establish, keep, or maintain, within the corporate limits of the city, any
stable, dog kennel, chicken coop or other similar structure wherein animals are
kept, for the purpose of breeding of animals of any kind, or in which acts of
copulation of domestic animals in public view are permitted. Each such place is
declared to be a public nuisance.
   E.   Inspections: Upon complaint of any person, the animal control officer
or other designated person shall inspect any stable, dog kennel, chicken coop
or other similar structure wherein animals are kept and may do so on his or her
own initiative. He or she may issue any such reasonable order as he or she may
deem necessary to the owner of the structure to cause the structure to be
maintained as provided by this article or in a manner so as not to constitute a
nuisance. He or she may make a complaint before the municipal court against any
person for violation of any provision of this article or of any such reasonable
order. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-11: DISEASED, INJURED, DEAD ANIMALS:
   A.   Diseased, Injured Animals:
      1.   It is unlawful for any person knowingly to bring into the city any
animal having any contagious disease, or to allow such animal to run at large
within the city.
      2.   It is unlawful for any person knowingly to sell, or to cause, allow,
or procure to be sold, any diseased or injured animal without disclosing such
disease to the prospective purchaser.
   B.   Dead Animals:
      1.   It is unlawful for any person to place or throw any injured or dead
animal in or upon any street, alley or public place within the city or to bury
any dead animal within the city.
      2.   It is the duty of the owner of any dead animal, or the person in
lawful possession of the same, to arrange with a private veterinarian or other
lawful service to dispose of the same in a humane and sanitary manner.
      3.   It is the duty of the owner or person in lawful possession of such
dead animal to place the remains in a sack, box or any other appropriate
receptacle before such disposition as provided by subsection B2 of this
section.
      4.   If the dead animal is too large for the owner feasibly to place the
remains in a sack, box or other appropriate receptacle, the owner shall notify
a private veterinarian to make arrangements for removal and disposal of the
remains.
      5.   It is the duty of any person upon whose premises a dead stray animal
is found, and if said person has no knowledge of the owner or person previously
in possession of the animal, to notify the animal control officer. Such person
shall not be liable to pay any fees for removal. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-12: TREATMENT OF ANIMALS:
   A.   Cruelty:
      1.   Prohibitions:
         a.   It is unlawful for any person to overdrive, overload, drive when
overloaded or overworked, torture, torment, deprive of necessary sustenance or
water, beat, mutilate, damage or kill any animal or fail to give such animal
sufficient sustenance and water, or to cause any animal to be so overdriven,
overloaded, driven when overloaded or overworked, tortured, tormented, deprived
of necessary sustenance or water, beaten, mutilated, damaged or killed.
         b.   It is unlawful for a person wilfully and unjustifiably to poison
any animal except a noxious wild animal; or knowingly to expose poison so that
the same may be taken by such animal.
      2.   Impoundment; Citation; Conditions Of Release; Euthanasia:
         a.   The animal control officer, upon finding an animal mistreated or
abused, shall impound the animal and cause a citation to be presented to the
municipal court for a violation of this chapter. The animal shall be maintained
at the pound or, if injured or diseased, in the care of a veterinarian, until
such time as the cause of mistreatment or abuse shall be rectified. The animal
control officer may further take any of the following actions:
            (1)   Specify terms and conditions under which the owner or keeper
may be allowed to regain custody of the animal at the expense of the owner for
costs of care incurred by the city.
            (2)   Obtain a court order to take permanent custody of any animal
found neglected or cruelly treated and remove the animal from its present
location.
            (3)   Within seven (7) days of seizure, petition the Tulsa County
district court for a bond hearing to determine cost and care for the animal. If
the court finds that probable cause exists that an animal has been abused, the
court may order immediate forfeiture of the animal to an agency designated by
the court. The court may also require that the owner or keeper post a security
bond in an amount to be determined by the court to be sufficient to reimburse
all reasonable and anticipated costs incurred by the agency caring for the
animal from the date of seizure. The bond shall be placed with the agency that
took custody of the animal, and the agency shall provide the court with an
accounting of expenses incurred. When all expenses covered by the bond are
exhausted and no subsequent bond has been posted, the animal shall be
permanently forfeited to the agency.
            (4)   If the animal is returned to the person who previously owned
or had charge or custody of the animal, funds not used for the care of the
animal shall be returned to such person.
            (5)   Euthanasia of a seized animal may be determined necessary at
any time by a veterinarian licensed by the state of Oklahoma or by a court of
competent jurisdiction.
         b.   The court shall have the authority to order the owner to provide
appropriate care to the animal or make arrangements for such appropriate care
to be given. All fines, court costs and charges for animal care, along with all
requirements for vaccination, registration and tags, shall be paid in full as a
condition of release. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
      3.   Penalties:
         a.   Any person who shall wilfully or maliciously torture, destroy or
kill, or cruelly beat or injure, maim or mutilate any animal in subjugation or
captivity, whether wild or tame, and whether belonging to the person or to
another, or deprive any such animal of necessary food, drink, shelter, or
veterinary care to prevent suffering; or who shall cause, procure or permit any
such animal to be so tortured, destroyed or killed, or cruelly beaten or
injured, maimed or mutilated, or deprived of necessary food, drink, shelter or
veterinary care to prevent suffering; or who shall wilfully instigate or engage
in or in any way further any act of cruelty to any animal, shall be guilty of a
felony, and any person reasonably suspected of such cruelty in the city shall
be referred to the office of the Tulsa County district attorney for possible
prosecution. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
         b.   Notwithstanding subsection A3a of this section, any person
reasonably suspected of committing any act of animal cruelty in the city, as
defined in subsection A1a or A2a of this section shall be subject to arrest and
prosecution in the city for a misdemeanor and subject to incarceration for up
to ten (10) days and/or a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   B.   Destruction Authorized:
      1.   Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions, any person may kill
an animal in self-defense or in defense of another when the animal, without
undue provocation, bites or attacks or attempts to bite or attack said person
in such manner that an ordinarily prudent person would be led to believe that
the person toward whom the animal's conduct is directed is about to be bitten
or otherwise physically harmed.
      2.   Notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions, any person may kill
an animal the appearance or conduct of which is such as would cause an
ordinarily prudent person to believe the animal to be afflicted with rabies and
the conduct of which is such that an ordinarily prudent person would believe
themselves to be in jeopardy of a bite or attack by such animal.
      3.   When, from any cause, it may happen that any domestic animal within
the corporate limits of the city shall be so wounded, maimed, sick, diseased or
injured as to render its recovery hopeless in the reasonable opinion of the
animal control officer, or as verified by a competent veterinarian, the animal
control officer may kill or destroy, or cause to be killed or destroyed, such
animal so injured or diseased as soon after such determination as practicable
and in such manner as in his or her judgment shall be the least painful. In the
event that the animal control officer kills or destroys such animal, he or she
will cause the carcass to be removed to such place as may be set apart for such
matter and disposed of as provided by ordinance for dead animals. In the event
that any person other than the animal control officer kills or destroys such
animal, such person will cause the carcass to be removed to such place as may
be set apart for such matter and disposed of as provided by ordinance for dead
animals.
   C.   Animal Fights: It is unlawful for any person to instigate or encourage
fighting between animals of any variety or for any purpose, commercial or
private; or to encourage one animal to attack, pursue or annoy another animal
except a noxious wild animal; or to keep a structure, pit or other place used
for fights between animals.
   D.   Transporting Animals In Vehicles: No person shall transport any animal
on any street, highway, alley or other public way in a motor vehicle unless the
animal is reasonably and securely enclosed in the vehicle, or reasonably and
safely secured by reasonable means subject to the control of the driver and/or
any passenger in the vehicle, cab, container, cage or other enclosing device or
confined by means of a humane tethering device sufficient to prevent the animal
from falling, being thrown or jumping from the vehicle. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-13: ITINERANT PEDDLING OF ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following words and
terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
    ITINERANT LOCATION: A nonfixed or nonpermanent business, residential,
private or public property location.
   ITINERANT PEDDLING: Engaging in the practice of selling or gifting of
animals without a kennel or other appropriate business license issued by the
city of Glenpool, regardless of location.
   B.   Prohibitions:
      1.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, firm or
corporation to peddle, by offering for sale or gift, any type of animal from an
itinerant location within the city limits.
      2.   It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, firm or
corporation to conduct the itinerant peddling, by offering for sale or gift, of
any type of animal from any location within the city limits. (Ord. 641, 10-25-
2010)
6-6A-14: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS:
In addition to the violation of any other express provision of this chapter, it
shall be an offense and a violation of this chapter, punishable as such in the
municipal court, for any owner of an animal to:
   A.   Abandon or desert any animal or to permit any animal to become a stray;
   B.   Allow any female to run at large while she is in season, whether she is
licensed or not;
   C.   Harbor, keep or have possession of any vicious animal;
   D.   Harbor, keep, or have possession of any dangerous animal, except under
conditions set forth in this article;
   E.   Harbor, keep, or have possession of any animal that is a nuisance,
except under conditions set forth in this article;
   F.   Allow any animal to be at large during the period of any epidemic of
rabies after proclamation of such epidemic;
   G.   Fail or refuse to deliver to the animal control officer or person
designated by him or her, upon demand, any unlicensed dog or cat, any dangerous
or vicious animal, any animal that is a nuisance, any animal suspected of
rabies or any animal found at large during the period of an epidemic of rabies,
or any animal, the keeping or harboring of which is otherwise declared to be an
offense;
   H.   Fail or refuse to comply with any sanitation rule or requirement set
forth or prescribed by the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance of
the city pertaining to sanitation;
   I.   Allow any animal to defecate (without the owner or such person removing
the excreta deposited) on public or private property other than that of the
owner; or
   J.   Otherwise do anything that is prohibited, or fail to do anything that
is required, by any part of this chapter. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-15: HOBBYIST EXEMPTION PERMIT:
   A.   Application For Permit; Issuance Or Denial; Fees:
      1.   Application for a hobbyist exemption permit shall be submitted in
writing to the animal control officer, who shall notify the applicant of
acceptance or denial within thirty (30) days from receipt of the application.
If such permit is denied, the applicant shall be informed of the reasons for
denial. If the permit is granted, the owner will be charged a fee as
established by the city council, plus any applicable costs, to obtain the
permit. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   The applicant must attest, in a signed written application, that he,
she or any entity under the control of him or her:
         a.   Is not a commercial breeder.
         b.   Is actively involved in a regionally or nationally recognized,
organized animal sport or hobby for at least one year prior to submitting the
application; such as:
            (1)   Participates in field trials using hunting dogs or
participates in hunting activities and holds a current, valid Oklahoma hunting
license; or
            (2)   Qualifies as an animal rescuer; or
            (3)   Performs in organized showmanship competitions.
         c.   Has not been convicted in the past ten (10) years of any offense
related to illegal commercial breeding, dogfighting, a nuisance offense,
cruelty to animals, a neglect offense or any violation of the Oklahoma wildlife
conservation code.
         d.   At the cost of the applicant, to be included as a cost for the
permit, a background check will be conducted to determine eligibility.
      3.   An applicant for a hobbyist exemption, in addition to the foregoing
written application, shall submit at least one of the following supporting
documents:
         a.   Certificates of training for at least two (2) training classes
dated within twenty four (24) months prior to the application; or
         b.   A show catalog identifying the applicant as an exhibitor, along
with two (2) superintendent's confirmation receipts of show, dated within
twenty four (24) months prior to the application; or
         c.   A certificate of title from a national registry for a dog or cat
owned by the applicant; or
         d.   Proof that a rescuer organization is a nonprofit animal welfare
organization incorporated in the state of Oklahoma, along with a list of all
persons authorized to serve as rescuers; or
         e.   Proof that the owner holds, or is exempt from holding, a current
valid Oklahoma hunting license.
   B.   Renewal Of Permit: A permit holder must reapply for the exemption
permit annually, at least thirty (30) days prior to expiration. Reapplication
requirements are the same as for initial application.
   C.   Additional Requirements Of Rescuer: Subject to the application
requirements of subsection B of this section, a rescuer may keep or harbor dogs
and/or cats in accordance with this section; provided, that such dogs and/or
cats are kept for no longer than ninety (90) days before either being relocated
to a permanent home or notifying the animal control officer.
   D.   Inspections:
      1.   The animal control officer will conduct at least one inspection, and
may conduct random subsequent inspections, of the housing facilities utilized
by the holders of an exemption permit prior to approval in order to confirm the
number of animals being housed there, the cleanliness of the facility and the
treatment of the animals, as well as to ensure compliance with this chapter.
      2.   If a facility housing animals under an exemption permit is found to
be in violation of any requirement for a permit, or otherwise in violation of
this chapter, the animal control officer shall remove animals from the facility
to the pound or to another agency and notify the owner that the owner has
seventy two (72) hours in which to remedy the violation. If the facility comes
into full compliance within such seventy two (72) hours, and all charges for
intermittent care are paid in full, the animals may be returned upon payment of
any impoundment fee or other applicable charges. If the violation is not
remedied within seven (7) days of the notice, the animal control officer shall
take steps necessary to present the matter to the municipal court, which shall
be authorized to designate any conditions of return.
   E.   Revocation Of Permit: A permit holder shall forfeit his or her
exemption permit if he or she is convicted of an offense, including illegal
commercial breeding, brokering dogfighting, nuisance, cruelty to animals or
violation of the Oklahoma wildlife conservation code.
   F.   Register Kept: The city clerk, or his or her designee, shall maintain a
register of qualified hobbyist exemption permit holders. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6A-16: KENNEL PROPRIETORS:
   A.   License Requirements:
      1.   Any person owning, operating or maintaining a kennel within or under
the jurisdiction of the city must first apply for and obtain a license to keep
and maintain such kennel. The issuance of a license shall be subject to any
applicable zoning conditions and to all other vaccination, registration and tag
requirements of this chapter.
      2.   It is unlawful for any person to be a "kennel proprietor", as
defined in section
6-6-1 of this chapter, within the city unless such proprietor shall first pay
to the city clerk an annual license fee in an amount established by the city
council. Upon proof of proper zoning and payment of such fee, the city clerk
shall furnish to such kennel proprietor a license to engage in such business.
(Ord. 641, 10-25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
      3.   The kennel proprietor's license fee shall be deemed to comply with
the registration, license and tag requirements of this chapter for dogs in such
kennel for only so long as they remain the property of the kennel proprietor.
   B.   Tags: It is the duty of the city clerk to furnish to each kennel
proprietor a sufficient number of tags upon each of which shall be engraved,
carved or stamped the year of the registration of such kennel and the number
under which the kennel was registered. The kennel proprietor shall tag each dog
in such kennel with one of the kennel tags in the same manner that other dogs
are tagged.
   C.   Confinement To Premises: All dogs in such kennel shall be at all times
confined on the premises of such kennel proprietor. Should any dog belonging
to, or kept by, such kennel proprietor be allowed off the premises of such
kennel proprietor, the owner or keeper thereof shall pay the same tag fee and
license fee thereon as is required by this chapter for all dogs not kept by a
kennel proprietor. Any such dog shall further be subject to all of the
provisions of this chapter, including seizure and impoundment, to the same
extent and in the same manner as any dog at large.
   D.   Sanitary Conditions: Such kennels shall be maintained at all times in a
clean and sanitary condition and shall be subject to inspection by the animal
control officer. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
ARTICLE B. DOG AND CAT LICENSING AND VACCINATION REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
6-6B-1: License And Vaccination Required
6-6B-2: Tag Fee; Registration Of Dog Or Cat
6-6B-3: Tag Requirements And Restrictions
6-6B-4: Register Kept
6-6B-1: LICENSE AND VACCINATION REQUIRED:
   A.   It is unlawful to own, keep, possess, harbor or allow to remain on
premises any dog or cat over six (6) months old, unless such dog or cat has a
current license and a current vaccination against rabies as required herein.
Such animals may be granted one year immunity from such vaccination
requirement; provided, that they have a current rabies vaccination license
issued by the United States department of agriculture such as that customarily
recognized for a period of one year.
   B.   The owner of a dog or cat shall have the dog or cat vaccinated against
rabies by a veterinarian or other authorized person every calendar year before
July 1 or, in the case of a pup or kitten, once it is six (6) months old. The
person vaccinating the dog or cat shall furnish the owner a certificate of
vaccination. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6B-2: TAG FEE; REGISTRATION OF DOG OR CAT:
   A.   Charges for unaltered and spayed or neutered animals are established by
the city council as tag fees and chargeable to the owner or other person in
possession and control of any dog or cat that has been in the city more than
six (6) months, whether from birth or from being brought into the city from
outside the city.
   B.   The tag fee imposed in this section shall not apply to a dog or cat
only temporarily brought and kept within the city, nor to a dog brought within
the city to participate in a dog show, nor to a service dog when such dog is
actually being used by a disabled or otherwise dependent person to aid him or
her in going from place to place, nor to dogs being kept by a kennel proprietor
or in pet shops for sale.
   C.   The tag fee imposed in this section shall be waived with respect to
owners aged sixty five (65) years or older; provided, however, that this shall
not lessen the duty of such owners to obtain registration and a tag.
   D.   The owner shall pay the tag fee imposed pursuant to this section to the
city clerk, and obtain a tag indicating the current year, for each calendar
year that the owner possesses the animal.
   E.   Before the city clerk accepts payment of the tag fee or issues a
license for the dog or cat, the person offering the tag fee shall present to
the city clerk the certificate of a veterinarian or other person legally
authorized to immunize dogs or cats, showing that the dog or cat has been
immunized against rabies during the calendar year, that is, since the preceding
December 31.
   F.   The owner of the dog or cat shall, at the time of paying the fee,
register the dog or cat by giving the city clerk the name and address of the
owner, the name, breed, color and sex of the dog or cat and such other
reasonable information as the city clerk may request. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010;
amd. 2013 Code)
6-6B-3: TAG REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Upon registration of the dog or cat, the city clerk shall cause to be
issued a tag showing the date of issuance, date of expiration, the name and
address of the owner or the person in whose name the license is issued, and
such other reasonable information as the city clerk may deem appropriate.
   B.   The owner of the animal shall cause the tag received from the city
clerk to be affixed to the collar of the dog or cat upon which the tag fee has
been paid in such a way as to be readily visible to officers of the city and
shall cause the tag to be so worn at all times. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
   C.   In the event a tag is lost before the end of the year for which it was
issued, the owner may secure a replacement tag by applying to the city clerk,
presenting the original receipt and paying a replacement fee as established by
the city council. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
   D.   No person shall counterfeit, or attempt to counterfeit, any tag issued
for a dog or cat as provided in this article, or take from any dog or cat a tag
legally placed thereon, or place such tag upon a dog or cat for which the tag
was not specifically issued. Any of these actions is a punishable offense.
(Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6B-4: REGISTER KEPT:
It is the duty of the city clerk or her/his designee to keep a register of all
animal licenses in the city, pursuant to the provisions of this article, and
such register shall show the date of the issuance of each license, its date of
expiration, and the name of the owner or the person in whose name the license
is issued and shall designate the size of the dog or cat and state as nearly as
possible the age, sex, color and breed of such dog or cat. It shall further
show the date of vaccination and by whom vaccinated. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
ARTICLE C. IMPOUNDMENT, REDEMPTION, ADOPTION
AND DISPOSITION
SECTION:
6-6C-1: Pound Established
6-6C-2: Impoundment Of Animals
6-6C-3: Redemption/Reclamation Of Impounded Animals
6-6C-4: Fees
6-6C-5: Adoption Of Impounded Animals Not Redeemed Or Reclaimed
6-6C-6: Disposition Of Unclaimed/Not Adopted Animals
6-6C-7: Records And Proceeds
6-6C-8: Prohibited Acts
6-6C-1: POUND ESTABLISHED:
A city pound is established under the jurisdiction of the police department and
the municipal court. It shall be under the immediate control of the animal
control officer or of such other person as may be officially designated. The
person in charge of the pound shall provide proper sustenance and water for all
animals impounded and shall treat them in a humane manner. (Ord. 702, 6-15-
2015)
6-6C-2: IMPOUNDMENT OF ANIMALS:
   A.   The animal control officer, a police officer or such other officer or
employee of the city as may be authorized by the city manager:
      1.   Shall take into custody and impound any "nuisance animal", any
"potentially dangerous dog", any "dangerous dog" or any animal running "at
large", as those terms are defined in section
6-6-1 of this chapter.
      2.   May, to the fullest extent necessary and without jeopardy to the
safety of him/herself or others, enter upon the premises of the owner of such
animal as described in subsection A1 of this section, or other public or
private premises to take such animal into custody.
      3.   If such animal cannot be apprehended with reasonable effort and
safety, may tranquilize or kill such animal as reasonably necessary and
justifiable under the circumstances, whether on private or public premises.
   B.   Any other person may take such animal into custody and deliver such
animal to the authority in charge of the pound for impoundment, provided that a
private citizen may not enter upon private premises of any other person to
effect capture of such animal.
   C.   The owner of any animal(s) that is/are taken into custody as provided
in this article, if charged with any violation of this chapter, shall be
presented to the municipal court on the earliest available docket to minimize
as much as feasible the term of such impoundment.
   D.   Any animal(s) captured and impounded as provided in this article whose
owner is not identified or whose owner is not compliant with or for any reason
not subject to the jurisdiction of the municipal court shall be dealt with in a
manner consistent with the provisions of this article.
   E.   Upon the passage of a minimum of five (5) days (120 hours) following
apprehension and impoundment of such an animal, unless the animal is being held
by the animal control officer pending the disposition of an action against the
owner or other responsible party, or upon the passage of a minimum of three (3)
days (72 hours) following adjudication of the animal's status by the municipal
court, the animal may be sold (adopted), euthanized or otherwise disposed of in
a humane manner by the animal control officer, provided the animal is not
redeemed by the owner or otherwise reclaimed by any person, all as provided in
this article. (Ord. 702, 6-15-2015)
6-6C-3: REDEMPTION/RECLAMATION OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS:
   A.   An owner of an impounded animal or his or her agent or another
responsible party, except in the case of an animal which is the subject of a
pending action in municipal court, may redeem or reclaim the animal, prior to
its sale (adoption), removal or destruction as provided for herein, by paying
the required fees as provided in section
6-6C-4 of this article, including impoundment fees, vaccination costs if
applicable and any assessed court fines or costs, upon providing satisfactory
proof of ownership or other responsibility and meeting any other requirements
which may be prescribed in this chapter.
   B.   Notwithstanding subsection A of this section, when, in the judgment of
the animal control officer pursuant to provisions of this chapter, an animal
being held pending adjudication by the municipal court should be further
detained, removed outside the jurisdiction of the city or euthanized for humane
reasons, the disposition of such animal may not be determined until the status
of such animal has been adjudicated by the municipal court.
   C.   An animal confined for rabies observation or other infectious disease
may not be reclaimed until the animal control officer authorizes the release
and in no case before the observation period is over.
   D.   An animal may be reclaimed by the owner within a minimum of five (5)
days (120 hours) following apprehension and impoundment if the animal is
registered and all applicable fees are paid, the owner or responsible party is
identifiable to the satisfaction of the animal control officer and any
applicable conditions regarding vaccination, spaying or neutering and other
necessary conditions have been met.
   E.   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection D of this section, in the
event an animal is being held for adjudication of its status by the municipal
court, such animal may be released within a minimum of three (3) days (72
hours) following adjudication by the municipal court, provided that all
applicable fines and court costs are paid in addition to satisfaction of the
conditions in subsection D of this section.
   F.   If an impounded animal is not spayed or neutered upon apprehension by
the animal control officer, the animal control officer will require that the
animal be spayed or neutered prior to release or reclamation at the sole
expense of the person seeking release or reclamation.
   G.   If an impounded animal is not current with vaccinations for rabies, the
animal control officer will require that the animal be vaccinated prior to
release or reclamation at the sole expense of the person seeking release or
reclamation. (Ord. 702, 6-15-2015)
6-6C-4: FEES:
   A.   The animal control officer, in conjunction with the city attorney and
the city clerk, shall determine fair and appropriate fees to be charged for
capturing, impounding, feeding, providing necessary medical care to and
otherwise tending to animals that are impounded in accordance with this
article; provided that, in no case, shall the fees exceed the actual cost to
the city. In computing the fee, a fraction of a day during which an animal is
impounded shall be deemed a full day.
   B.   Any person redeeming an animal not licensed as required by this chapter
shall pay the required registration and license tag fee to the city clerk and
present the receipt therefor to the animal control officer before the animal
may be released. If an animal has been licensed, the animal control officer
shall require sufficient evidence of the proper licensing of the animal before
releasing it.
   C.   Any person redeeming an impounded animal shall pay the required fees,
along with any applicable fines and costs owing to the municipal court, to the
court clerk and shall present his or her receipt therefor, along with proof of
vaccination and registration as otherwise required by this chapter, to the
animal control officer before the animal may be released.
   D.   The foregoing fees apply only to the redemption and reclamation of
animals impounded for violations of this chapter. Fees applicable to the
adoption of animals not otherwise redeemed or reclaimed shall be exclusively
those identified in section
6-6C-5 of this article. (Ord. 702, 6-15-2015)
6-6C-5: ADOPTION OF IMPOUNDED ANIMALS NOT REDEEMED OR RECLAIMED:
   A.   If the owner of an impounded animal cannot be identified by tag or
otherwise, or if no identified owner or other responsible party undertakes to
redeem or reclaim such animal, the animal control officer shall publish notice
that the animal may be sold (adopted), removed from the jurisdiction of the
city or euthanized upon the passage of a minimum of five (5) days (120 hours)
following impoundment or, if being held pending adjudication in the municipal
court, upon the passage of a minimum of three (3) days (72 hours) following
such adjudication.
   B.   Contents of the notice must include, at a minimum and not limited to,
the following information:
The following animal(s): [to be identified by picture, name if known, species
of animal, breed (if known) and such other descriptive features as may be
helpful to recognition by an interested party] has/have been apprehended and
impounded in the pound of the City of Glenpool, Oklahoma for (describe
offense), which is contrary to provisions of the ordinances of the City of
Glenpool. Such animals, having not been redeemed or reclaimed within the time
periods established by ordinance, have been deemed eligible for adoption by the
first qualified person to make application to the animal control officer and
pay all costs imposed on the face of the application to the animal control
officer. Qualifications for adoption, and the fees for adoption, shall be
determined in accordance with the terms of an adoption application form.
   C.   The notice shall be published as follows:
      1.   If the owner or other responsible party is known, notice may be
given in person or by certified mail to the owner or may be left at the owner's
address with a person fourteen (14) years of age or older.
      2.   Posted for public display within the lobby of the police department
and the utility billing building.
      3.   Displayed on the city website or any other public media site
operated by the city of Glenpool.
      4.   Notice must be so published for no fewer than five (5) days (120
hours) before adoption is undertaken.
   D.   Adoption sales herein provided for shall be for cash or certified funds
to the first interested party with ability to pay and who completes an adoption
application in a form to be prescribed by the city attorney and the city clerk,
as the same may be from time to time amended in ways not inconsistent with the
provisions of this chapter.
   E.   Application forms for adoption shall be submitted to the animal control
officer who shall approve or deny such application in his or her sole
discretion reasonably applied and adoptions shall be conducted by, or under the
direction of, the animal control officer.
   F.   If there is no interest in an animal offered for adoption, the animal
control officer may euthanize the animal, or have it euthanized, in a humane
manner.
   G.   The purchaser of an animal by sale (adoption) held as provided herein,
shall acquire absolute title to the animal purchased and shall be responsible
for all registration fees, neutering or spaying, vaccinations and such other
acts as may be required by this chapter.
   H.   The animal control officer shall pay to the city clerk all monies
received from the sale (adoption) of impounded animals on the day they are
received or on the immediately next day upon which the office of the city clerk
is open for business. (Ord. 702, 6-15-2015)
6-6C-6: DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED/NOT ADOPTED ANIMALS:
   A.   If, in the judgment and discretion of the animal control officer or if
so adjudicated by the municipal court, any impounded animal that is not
redeemed or reclaimed by its owner or another responsible party, and is not
adopted, or for any humane reason should be removed from the jurisdiction of
the city or be destroyed, then the animal control officer may, after a minimum
of five (5) days (120 hours) after the time for reclaiming such animal has
expired, euthanize or cause the animal to be removed from the jurisdiction of
the city or euthanized and, in the case of euthanasia, cause the body thereof
to be disposed of as required by applicable law.
   B.   Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection A of this section, if in
the judgment and discretion of the animal control officer or if so adjudicated
by the municipal court, any animal shall be deemed not eligible for redemption,
reclamation or removal from the jurisdiction because it presents an immediate
and irremediable threat to public health or safety, then the animal control
officer shall promptly euthanize or cause the animal to be euthanized and cause
the body thereof to be disposed of as required by applicable law. (Ord. 702, 6-
15-2015)
6-6C-7: RECORDS AND PROCEEDS:
It is the duty of the animal control officer to enter into a logbook to be kept
in his or her office for that purpose the description and date of the seizure
of all animals taken under the provisions of this chapter, the place where
impoundment occurred, the cause for impoundment, the name of the owner if
known, the date of any notice(s) posted, and all subsequent proceedings
relating to the disposition of the animal, including adoption and the amount
realized if adopted pursuant to this article. All fees and proceeds of sales
(adoption) collected by the animal control officer shall be paid to the city
clerk. (Ord. 702, 6-15-2015)
6-6C-8: PROHIBITED ACTS:
No unauthorized person shall:
   A.   Break or attempt to break open the pound, or take out or release any
animal therefrom.
   B.   Take or attempt to take from any officer or employee of the city any
animal taken into custody as provided by this chapter.
   C.   In any manner interfere with or hinder an officer or employee in the
discharge of his or her duties relating to the taking into custody and
impounding of animals as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 702, 6-15-2015)
ARTICLE D. RABIES CONTROL
SECTION:
6-6D-1: Confinement Of Animals
6-6D-2: Animal Bites; Quarantine
6-6D-3: Death Of Diagnosed Animal; Support Information
6-6D-4: Rabies Crisis
6-6D-5: Surrender Of Rabies Suspects
6-6D-6: Killing Rabid Animals
6-6D-1: CONFINEMENT OF ANIMALS:
When the animal control officer, or person designated by him or her, determines
and certifies that a dog, a cat or other animal in the city or within five (5)
miles of the city is or was infected with rabies and that an epidemic of rabies
threatens the city, the council, by resolution, may order all dogs to be
confined and, if deemed desirable, all cats to be confined during a period of
time to be determined by the council. Such resolution or an adequate notice of
its passage shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the
city and shall go into effect on the day following such publication unless the
resolution prescribes a later time. While such resolution is in effect, it is
unlawful for any owner to permit a dog or cat to be at large in violation of
such resolution. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6D-2: ANIMAL BITES; QUARANTINE:
The identity and address of the owner of any animal that bites a person shall
be promptly furnished to the animal control officer, the city health officer,
if any, and the county health department. The animal control officer shall
securely quarantine such animal for a period of ten (10) days and shall not
release such quarantined animal until reasonable determination has been made
that the animal is not infected with rabies. Such quarantine shall be at a
veterinary hospital of the owner's choice at the owner's expense or at the city
animal shelter, only if conditions are deemed appropriate by the animal control
officer. The animal may be reclaimed by the owner if adjudged free of rabies,
and such owner shall then pay any related charges for confinement. (Ord. 641,
10-25-2010)
6-6D-3: DEATH OF DIAGNOSED ANIMAL; SUPPORT INFORMATION:
When an animal under quarantine has been diagnosed by a licensed veterinarian
as being rabid or is suspected of having rabies and dies while under such
observation, the animal control officer, veterinarian, the city health officer,
if any, or other designated person shall immediately send the necessary part of
such animal to the state health department for pathological examination and
shall notify the proper public health officer of any reports of human contact.
(Ord. 641, 10-25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
6-6D-4: RABIES CRISIS:
   A.   Declaration: When a report gives a suspected or a positive diagnosis of
rabies, or when city, county or state health officials feel that a rabies
crisis may be imminent, such health officials may recommend to the city manager
a citywide quarantine and, upon invoking of such quarantine by the city
council, by resolution, no animal shall be taken into the streets or permitted
to be in the streets, except for short periods of exercise under leash and
control of a competent adult. During the quarantine, no animal may be taken or
removed from the city without written permission of the animal control officer.
This declaration must be made by notice in a general circulated newspaper of
the community and will last as long as health officials determine the situation
requires such action.
   B.   Destruction Of Animals Under Crisis Period: During any period of rabies
quarantine, every animal bitten by an animal adjudged to be rabid shall be
destroyed or, at the owner's expense and option, shall be treated for a rabies
infection by a licensed veterinarian, or held under six (6) month quarantine by
the owner in the same manner as a female in season. The period of quarantine
may be extended from time to time. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6D-5: SURRENDER OF RABIES SUSPECTS:
No person shall remove from the city any animal suspected of having been
exposed to rabies, or any animal which has bitten a human, except as herein
provided. The carcass of any dead animal exposed to rabies shall be surrendered
to the animal control officer upon demand, and the animal control officer shall
direct disposition of the animal. No person shall refuse to surrender any
animal for quarantine or destruction when such demand is lawfully made by the
animal control officer. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6D-6: KILLING RABID ANIMALS:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, any person may kill an
animal the appearance or conduct of which is such as would cause an ordinarily
prudent person to believe the animal to be afflicted with rabies and the
conduct of which is such that an ordinarily prudent person would believe
themselves to be in jeopardy of a bite or attack by such animal. (Ord. 641, 10-
25-2010)
ARTICLE E. EXOTIC ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-6E-1: Definition
6-6E-2: Prohibited Exotic Animals
6-6E-3: Permit Requirements
6-6E-4: Health Requirements
6-6E-5: Housing And Care
6-6E-6: Inspections
6-6E-7: Impoundment And Reclamation
6-6E-8: Revocation Of Permit
6-6E-9: Miniature Pigs
6-6E-1: DEFINITION:
An "exotic" animal is defined as any animal not normally considered
domesticated, and shall include, but not be limited to:
   A.   Class Reptilia: Order Phidia (such as racers, boas, water snakes and
pythons) and order Loricata (such as alligators and crocodiles).
   B.   Class Aves: Order Falconiforms (such as hawks, eagles and vultures) and
subdivision Ratitae (such as ostriches, rheas, cassowaries and emus).
   C.   Class Mammalia: Order Carnivora, family Felidae (such as ocelots,
tigers, jaguars, leopards and cougars), except commonly accepted domesticated
cats; the family Canidae (such as wolves, dingos, coyotes and jackals), except
domesticated dogs (unless, after complaint and investigation by the city
manager or his designee, the dog is determined to be vicious or has previously
attacked or bitten a person); family Mustelidae (such as weasels, minks and
badgers); family Procynnidae (raccoons); family Ursidae (such as bears); and
order Marsupialia (such as kangaroos and common opossums), order Edentata (such
as sloths, anteaters and armadillos), order Proboscidea (elephants), order
Primata (such as monkeys, chimpanzees and gorillas), order Rodenta (such as
porcupines) and order Ungulata (such as antelope, deer, bison, camels, and
potbellied pigs). (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-2: PROHIBITED EXOTIC ANIMALS:
The following exotic animals are prohibited:
   A.   Any exotic animal or species prohibited by federal and/or Oklahoma law.
   B.   Any exotic animal or species when kept in such numbers or in such a way
as to constitute likelihood of harm to the animals themselves, to human beings
or to the property of human beings, or which constitute a public or private
nuisance.
   C.   Bats.
   D.   Skunks.
   E.   Bears.
   F.   Bison.
   G.   Any large, nondomesticated, carnivorous animal in the family Felidae
(such as ocelots, tigers, jaguars, leopards, and cougars), in the family
Canidae (such as wolves, dingos, coyotes and jackals) and in the family Ursidae
(such as bears).
   H.   Two (2) or more exotic animals of any type over six (6) months of age
unless the premises upon which the exotic animals are housed is zoned
commercial or agriculture general.
   I.   Notwithstanding the above, a licensed zoological park, veterinary
hospital, Humane Society, licensed shelter, public laboratory, circus,
sideshow, or educational or scientific facility is excluded from the
prohibitions of this section so long as such entity provides protective devices
adequate to prevent such animals from escaping or injuring the public and is
otherwise permissible under all applicable city codes and ordinances.
   J.   Except as otherwise permitted in accordance with this article, the
following animals are absolutely prohibited within the city, and their
possession shall constitute a punishable offense:
Apes, chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans, baboons or other similar animals
generally within the family of monkeys.
Cheetahs.
Constrictor snakes or any venomous snakes.
Crocodiles.
Deer.
Gamecocks.
Hippopotamuses.
Hyenas, jaguars, tigers, lions and leopards.
Ostriches.
Piranhas.
Sharks.
Wolves or coyotes. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-3: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required:
      1.   No person shall receive, purchase, own or keep any exotic animal
without first applying for and receiving a permit to do so. Persons in
possession of exotic animals when they become residents of the city or who
possess exotic animals on the effective date hereof shall have a fifty (50) day
period in which to apply for said permit before the penalty provisions of this
chapter become applicable.
      2.   No person shall apply for an exotic animal permit without first
obtaining any required state or federal permits.
   B.   Application For Permit: The application for a permit shall contain the
name of the applicant; his address, phone number, social security number, date
of birth, the address of the proposed location of the exotic animal(s), if
different from the applicant's; a brief description of the applicant's plan for
keeping the exotic animal(s) which shall include the species of animal, the
number of individuals of each species, and a description of the housing
facilities; a list of individuals qualified to care for the animal(s) or that
have agreed to advise or assist the applicant in the proper care and treatment
of the animal(s) and who would be willing to recommend the person applying for
the permit; the list of publications which the applicant has studied in order
to qualify for a permit for the said animal(s).
   C.   Property Owner Approval Required: If the property on which the exotic
animal is to be located is not owned by the applicant, then written approval of
the property owner to have an exotic animal on the premises shall be provided.
(Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
   D.   Fee And Insurance:
      1.   The application shall be submitted with a nonrefundable application
fee as established by the city council. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   In addition, the applicant shall provide evidence of public
liability insurance coverage in an amount of not less than fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000.00), and specifically including any prospective damage
resulting from ownership of the animals as a covered event.
   E.   Inspections And Investigations: Upon receipt of the application, the
animal control officer and/or other qualified person designated by the city
manager shall inspect the facilities where the animal(s) is to be housed and
shall make whatever other investigations and impose whatever conditions they
deem necessary to protect the public interest.
   F.   Notices:
      1.   At the applicant's expense, notice of the hearing before the city
council on consideration of the application for an exotic animal permit shall
be given to all landowners within a three hundred foot (300') radius of the
exterior property boundary on which the exotic animal is to be housed by first
class mailing at least fifteen (15) days prior to the proposed hearing. Such
notice will specify the type(s) of exotic animal(s) to be housed and the
location thereof and the date, time, and place of the hearing.
      2.   In addition, the applicant shall post notice on the property,
pursuant to the zoning regulations for same, where the exotic animal will be
housed for at least fifteen (15) continuous days prior to the city council
hearing date that the application for an exotic animal permit shall be
considered and specifying the date, time and place of the hearing.
   G.   Issuance Of Permit; Term; Renewals:
      1.   If the city council approves the application by finding that the
granting of such permit will not constitute a menace to the health, peace or
safety of the community and that adequate safeguards have been made, then the
permit shall be issued by the city clerk and shall be valid for one calendar
year. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
      2.   The exotic animal permit must be renewed within thirty (30) days
after its expiration, and an inspection shall be required prior to the renewal
of the exotic animal permit. The annual fee for renewal of an exotic animal
permit shall be as established by the city council, which fee shall include the
cost of one inspection. Additional inspections to add more exotic animals or to
determine whether deficiencies exist or have been corrected shall be as
established by the city council for each exotic animal. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010;
amd. 2013 Code)
   H.   Additional Animals; Additional Permits:
      1.   Whenever a new exotic animal is added, except for newborns under six
(6) months of age, a new application for permit must be secured and a new
application fee shall be due and payable at the time of application for the
permit and shall be a prerequisite to issuance of a permit for the new exotic
animal.
      2.   If, during the preceding year, more than the initial permit has been
issued for the applicant, the former permits may be consolidated so that only
one renewal permit is required; provided, however, that the renewal date for
the consolidated permit shall be the date of the issuance of the earliest
initial permit. The city manager or his or her designee may deny the
application for renewal for cause. If a renewal permit is denied, the applicant
may appeal the denial to the city council within fifteen (15) days of notice of
denial by filing a written notice of appeal with the city clerk.
   I.   Change Of Residence Or Location:
      1.   A change of residence of the applicant for an exotic animal permit
or change of location for the permitted exotic animal(s) shall require a new
application and permit within fifteen (15) days of the change in residence or
location.
      2.   The exotic animal permittee must notify the city clerk when changing
residence or location on which the exotic animal(s) is maintained or selling or
otherwise disposing of the exotic animal(s) for which the permit was issued
within fifteen (15) days of such action. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-4: HEALTH REQUIREMENTS:
Individuals prospectively permitted to house an exotic animal must, within
fifteen (15) days of acquisition, submit to the animal control officer or his
or her designee, a health certificate from a qualified veterinarian stating
that the animal has been vaccinated in accordance with applicable laws and time
schedules. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-5: HOUSING AND CARE:
   A.   Housing for exotic animal(s) shall be sufficiently spacious and
ventilated and shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times, such sufficiency
to be determined by a qualified person.
   B.   The exotic animal(s) shall be provided with proper food, water and
attention and not exposed to cruel or inhumane treatment.
   C.   The exotic animal(s) shall be kept and cared for in such a way as to
not endanger the safety of any person or property. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-6: INSPECTIONS:
Premises for which permits are issued pursuant to the provisions of this
article shall be available for inspection upon request of the animal control
officer or his or her designee. Such premises shall be open at any reasonable
hour and in a reasonable manner for such inspection to be conducted in a safe
and convenient manner. In the event of failure of any permittee to abide by the
requirements herein, the permit may be withdrawn by the animal control officer
or his or her designee. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-7: IMPOUNDMENT AND RECLAMATION:
   A.   Impoundment:
      1.   For failure to have a permit in advance of obtaining an exotic
animal or to renew said permit within thirty (30) days of the expiration date,
or upon suspension of an exotic animal permit for any reason consistent with
the provisions of this article, the animal control officer or his or her
designee shall have the authority to enter the premises where the exotic animal
is kept at any reasonable hour to impound such animal or, as necessary, have it
impounded by a third party agency. In either case, all costs of impoundment
shall be paid by the owner of the animal.
      2.   In case of an emergency, the animal control officer or his or her
designee shall have the authority to enter the premises where the exotic animal
is kept and to impound said animal. The animal shall be surrendered upon
demand.
   B.   Reclamation: Procedures for reclamation and possible destruction of
impounded exotic animals shall be followed pursuant to advisement of an expert
consultant. The exotic animal may be returned to its owner if the problem for
which it was impounded is corrected within seven (7) days of its capture and
all penalties and charges are paid.
   C.   Impoundment Facility: In the event the city pound facility is
inadequate for housing the impounded exotic animal, the city may have the same
housed at another facility, and the owner of such exotic animal shall be
responsible for all costs incurred, regardless of amount.
   D.   Destruction Authorized: In the event an exotic animal is a threat to
the individual seeking to impound it, the impounding person may have the exotic
animal humanely destroyed. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-8: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
An exotic animal permit may be revoked by the animal control officer for any of
the following reasons: false or misleading information on an application for an
exotic animal permit or a renewal permit; failure to secure an additional
permit within the proscribed time period when an additional exotic animal is
located on the premises; changes in the character of the premises on which the
exotic animal is located, or the adjacent areas, which would cause the
continued retention of the exotic animal to be a threat to safety of the public
or a nuisance, or endangerment of the exotic animal; failure to abide by the
provisions of this article regulating exotic animals; or failure to take
corrective action as may be directed by the animal control officer or his or
her designee to correct noted deficiencies. (Ord. 641, 10-25-2010)
6-6E-9: MINIATURE PIGS:
A miniature pig may be kept as merchandise in commercially zoned property or
may be kept as a household pet in a single-family residential or duplex
property under the following conditions:
   A.   Each such miniature pig shall be a pet which is kept for personal
enjoyment and not raised for human consumption.
   B.   There shall not be more than two (2) miniature pigs in excess of six
(6) months of age at any residence.
   C.   Miniature pigs must be kept by their owner(s) in a manner that does not
violate this chapter or other ordinances of the city nor create a nuisance to
the neighborhood.
   D.   Miniature pigs must be kept confined within the building in which they
are housed or within any associated fenced yards, or held by a harness and
leash under the control of the owner or the owner's representative. (Ord. 641,
10-25-2010)
TITLE 7
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL TRAFFIC PROVISIONS
SECTION:
7-1-1: State Regulations Adopted
